{{Infobox document |document_name = Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions |image = Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions.png |image_width = 200px |image_caption = First page of the Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions<ref>[http://www.nnp.org/annals/2000.pdf Gehring], pp. 4</ref> |date_created = |date_ratified = June 7, 1629 |location_of_document = [[Netherlands]] |writer = [[Dutch West India Company]] |signers = |purpose = Establish [[patroonship]]s in [[New Netherland]] }}
The '''Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions''',<ref name=vrbm137>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA137#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 137</ref> sometimes referred to as the '''Charter of Privileges and Exemptions''',<ref name=chamber26>[https://books.google.com/books?id=t3MTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA26#v=onepage&q=&f=false New Netherland Chamber of Commerce in America], pp. 26</ref> is a document written by the [[Dutch West India Company]] in an effort to settle its [[colony]] of [[New Netherland]] in [[North America]] through the establishment of feudal [[patroonship]]s purchased and supplied by members of the West India Company. Its 31 articles establish ground rules and expectations of the patroons and inhabitants of the new colonies. It was ratified by the [[Dutch Republic|Dutch]] [[States-General of the Netherlands|States-General]] on June 7, 1629.<ref name = vrbm137/><ref>[https://archive.org/stream/vanrensselaerfam21spoo#page/8/mode/1up Spooner], pp. 8</ref>
==Background== {{New Netherland}}
The economic situation of the colony of New Netherland in the late 1620s could be considered a fairly good showing for a colony only newly started in a wilderness.<ref name = chamber26/> The first settlement was built in 1613, strictly out of necessity, but soon after, forts were built. At the time of the charter, the oldest settlement was only 16 years old.<ref>{{Cite web| last = Welling| first = George M.| title = The United States of America and the Netherlands: The First Dutch Settlers| work = From Revolution to Reconstruction| accessdate =| date = 24 November 2004| url = http://odur.let.rug.nl/~usa/E/newnetherlands/nl2.htm}}</ref> But this slow success was hardly sufficient to create much excitement among the directors of the West India Company. The principal objective of this organization was to go after the spoils of war, which promised rich harvests in the captured fleets of the [[Spain|Spanish]], with colonization being only a secondary consideration. Noting that the capture of the [[Spanish treasure fleet|silver fleet]] in 1628 left the company proceeds of $115,000,000, and that the next year sundry privateers brought in a bounty of over $18,000,000, it was hardly surprising that so little attention was paid to the settlements in the [[Hudson Valley|Hudson River Valley]]. Those were "get rich quick" days for large corporations, and the slow and tedious procedure of colonizing and cultivating new countries found little favor in the eyes of the men at the helm.<ref name = chamber26/>
==The Charter== The realization that greater inducements had to be offered to increase the development of the colony led the West India Company to the creation of the so-called "[[patroon|patroon system]]". In 1629, the West India Company issued its charter of "Freedoms and Exemptions" by which it was declared that any member of the Company who could bring to and settle 50 persons over the age of 15 in New Netherland, should receive a liberal grant of land to hold as ''patroon'', or lord, with the exception, per [[:wikisource:Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions#Article III|Article III]], of the island of [[Manhattan]]. This land could have a frontage of {{convert|16|mi|km}} if on one side of a river, or {{convert|8|mi|km}} if situated on both sides. The patroon would be chief [[magistrate]] on his land, but disputes of more than 50 [[guilder]]s could be appealed to the [[Director of New Netherland|Director]] and his Council in [[New Amsterdam]].
The tenants would be free from all taxation for 10 years, but during this period they would not be allowed to change from one estate to another nor to move from the country to the town. At least one quarter of the 50 inhabitants would have to be settled within the first year of the land grant, with the rest being settled within three years following that. The patroons would have full liberty to purchase goods in New Netherland, [[New England]], and [[New France]], with the exception of furs. But the trader would have to pay an export tax of five per cent in New Amsterdam before goods could be shipped to [[Europe]]. The [[Fur trade#North American fur trade|fur trade]] remained a monopoly of the Company, being the most profitable investment at the time. The weaving of cloth was also prohibited in order to supply the looms in Holland with their needed raw supplies.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=t3MTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA26#v=onepage&q=&f=false Netherland Chamber of Commerce in America], pp. 26–27</ref>
The patroon would be responsible for the expenses in erecting barns and other structures and preparing land for farming in addition to supplying the initial farming tools, vehicles, and livestock. However, each tenant would be due to pay a stipulated rent in addition to a percentage of that which they produced. Additionally, no farmer could sell any good without first offering it to patroon. The patroon also bore responsibility of hiring a minister and schoolmaster, as well as financing the respective structures when they became needed. Once the patroonship became a profitable enterprise, the patroon was expected to share net profits with the tenants.<ref name=colton45>[https://books.google.com/books?id=WgpsNImMvP8C&lpg=PA43&ots=aPiBwEpTyX&dq=%22charter%20of%20freedoms%20and%20exemptions%22&pg=PA45#v=onepage&q=&f=false Colton], p. 45</ref>
There are some notable aspects of the charter, which, while aiming to make the West India Company wealthy and successful, offered great incentives to the patroons and respect to the indigenous peoples. For example, [[:wikisource:Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions#Article XXVI|Article XXVI]] states that the patroon "must satisfy the Indians of that place for the land", essentially implying that the land must be bought (or [[barter]]ed) from the local Indians, and not just taken. [[:wikisource:Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions#Article VI|Article VI]] states that the patroon "shall forever own and possess and hold from the Company as a perpetual fief of inheritance, all the land lying within the aforesaid limits", which made the patroonship a [[fiefdom]]. It shall be seen later that one patroonship would last well into the 19th century. Additionally, the Company agreed to protect the patroonships from attack ([[:wikisource:Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions#Article XXV|Article XXV]]), and even supply the patroonship—for free—"with as many [[African slave trade|blacks]] as it possibly can ... for [no] longer [a] time than it shall see fit" ([[:wikisource:Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions#Article XXX|Article XXX]]).<ref>{{Cite wikisource|title=Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions|author=Dutch West India Company|year=1629|others=Trans. Arnold Johan Ferdinand Van Laer}}</ref>
==Resulting patroonships== {{main|Patroon}} [[File:Delaware Bay Vinckeboons 14.jpg|thumb|250px|Nautical chart of [[Zwaanendael]], 1639]] The earliest venture to explore New Netherland for future colonization by a potential patroon was upon notification to the Directors on January 13, 1629 that [[Samuel Godyn]], [[Kiliaen van Rensselaer (Dutch merchant)|Kiliaen van Rensselaer]], and [[Samuel Blommaert]] had sent Gillis Houset and Jacob Jansz Cuyper to determine satisfactory locations for settlement. This took place before the Charter was ratified, but was done in agreement with a draft of the Charter from March 28, 1628.<ref name = vrbm154>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA154#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 154</ref>
Upon ratification of the charter on June 7, 1629, [[Michael Reyniersz Pauw|Michael Pauw]] informed the Directors of his intention to settle along the "Sickenames River", a stream east of the [[Connecticut River]].<ref name=vrbm154155>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA154#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscript], pp. 154–155</ref> On June 19, Samuel Godyn declared his intention to settle "the bay of the South River", the current day [[Delaware Bay]], naming the settlement [[Zwaanendael]].<ref name=vrbm155>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA155#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bower Manuscripts], pp. 155</ref> After the settlement had been in existence for only a short while, the colonists—32 in number—were murdered by the local [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indians]].<ref name=chamber27>[https://books.google.com/books?id=t3MTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q=&f=false Netherland Chamber of Commerce in America], pp. 27</ref> Godyn sold his holdings back to the West India Company.<ref name = vrbm164/>
Patroonships were not limited to the area of the [[northeastern United States]]. On October 15, Michael Pauw made his intention known to settle the islands of [[Fernando de Noronha]], located off the [[Brazil]]ian coast.<ref name=vrbm155/> Likewise on October 22, Albertus Conradus declared himself patroon of the [[Saint Vincent (island)|island of Saint Vincent]].<ref name = vrbm156>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA156#v=onepage&q=%22st%20vincent%22&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 156</ref> On November 1, Conradus also registered as patroon of the east side of [[Delaware Bay|South Bay]], that which had not been taken by Samuel Godyn on June 19.<ref name = vrbm156/> It was abandoned and no colony was actually established.<ref name = vrbm164>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA164#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 164</ref>
On November 16, 1629, Samuel Blommaert declared himself patroon of the Fresh River{{Ref_label|a|a|none}} presumedly adjoining the one to the east on the Sickenames River previously registered by Michael Pauw.<ref name=vrbm157>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA157#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 157</ref> No colony was ever established and the patroonship was eventually abandoned.<ref name = vrbm165>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA165#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscript], pp. 165</ref> On January 10, 1630, Pauw declared himself patroon of an area along the southern end of the North River,{{Ref_label|b|b|none}} including land on the present site of [[Jersey City]],<ref name=chamber27/> and [[Staten Island]], so called in honor of the ''"Staten"'', or States General.<ref name=colton47>[https://books.google.com/books?id=WgpsNImMvP8C&lpg=PA43&ots=aPiBwEpTyX&dq=%22charter%20of%20freedoms%20and%20exemptions%22&pg=PA47#v=onepage&q=&f=false Colton], p. 47</ref> The patroonship was called [[Pavonia, New Netherland|Pavonia]].<ref name = vrbm158>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA158#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 158</ref> The enterprise however, was not a financial success and he finally sold his holdings to the West India Company.<ref name=chamber27/>
The most successful of the settlements started under the patroonship charter was on the upper [[Hudson River]] by [[Kiliaen van Rensselaer (Dutch merchant)|Kiliaen van Rensselaer]], an [[Amsterdam]] jeweler and member of the Chamber of Amsterdam.<ref name = chamber28>[https://books.google.com/books?id=t3MTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA28#v=onepage&q=&f=false Netherland Chamber of Commerce in America], pp. 27–28</ref> Van Rensselaer declared his intentions of settling a patroonship on November 19, 1629.<ref name = vrbm157/> From the [[Mahicans]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Contract of sale of land along the Hudson River from the Mahican Indians to Kiliean Van Rensselaer |url=http://nysl.nysed.gov/uhtbin/cgisirsi/6YXwYaAdUR/NYSL/278040007/523/74529 |date=6 August 1630 |last=Crol |first=Bastiaen Janssen |accessdate=2009-08-07 |format=JPEG, browser pop-up blocker must be disabled }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> he purchased a plot of land now represented by [[Albany County, New York|Albany]] and [[Rensselaer County|Rensselaer]] counties, which he called [[Rensselaerswyck]] and to which he brought several families from the town of [[Nijkerk]], the place of his birth.<ref name = chamber28/> Rensselaerswyck would stay in the van Rensselaer family until its dissolution during the [[Anti-Rent War]] in the 1840s, with its last patroon, [[Stephen van Rensselaer III]] dying a very rich man.<ref>Ellis, pp. 158–161</ref> To this day, he is listed as the tenth richest American in history, having been worth about $10 million (about $88 billion in 2007 dollars).<ref>{{cite news |title=The richest Americans: Stephen Van Rensselaer |last=Klepper |first=M. |author2=R. Gunther |publisher=[[Fortune Magazine]] |url=http://money.cnn.com/galleries/2007/fortune/0702/gallery.richestamericans.fortune/10.html |accessdate=2009-06-28}}</ref>
==Notes== {{refbegin}} *'''a.''' {{Note_label|a|a|none}} The original Dutch name for the [[Connecticut River]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&dq=The%20Van%20Rensselaers%20in%20Holland%20and%20in%20America&pg=PA861#v=onepage&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 861</ref> *'''b.''' {{Note_label|b|b|none}} The original Dutch name for the [[Hudson River]].<ref name=vrbm876>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0FIOAAAAIAAJ&vq=%22North%20River%22&pg=PA876#v=thumbnail&q=&f=false Van Rensselaer Bowier Manuscripts], pp. 876</ref> {{refend}}

[[Labour candidates and parties in Canada|Independent Labour Party]] | successor = [[Ontario New Democratic Party]] | position = [[Left-wing politics|Left-wing]] | colours = [[Green]] and [[Yellow]] }} The '''Co-operative Commonwealth Federation (Ontario Section) – The Farmer-Labor Party of Ontario''', or more commonly known as '''the Ontario CCF''', was a [[democratic socialism|democratic socialist]] political party that existed from 1932 to 1961. It was the provincial wing of the [[Co-operative Commonwealth Federation|national CCF]]. The party had no leader in the beginning, and was governed by a provincial council and executive. The party's first Member of the Legislative Assembly (MLA) was elected by voters in the [[Ontario general election, 1934|1934 Ontario general election]]. In the [[Ontario general election, 1937|1937 general election]], no CCF members were elected to the Ontario Legislature. In 1942, the party elected Toronto lawyer [[Ted Jolliffe]] as its first leader. He led the party to within a few seats of forming the government in the [[Ontario general election, 1943|1943 general election]]; instead, it formed the [[Leader of the Opposition (Ontario)|Official Opposition]]. In that election, the first two women were elected to the Ontario Legislature as CCFers: [[Agnes Macphail]] and [[Rae Luckock]]. The [[Ontario general election, 1945|1945 election]] was a setback, as the party lost most of its seats in the Legislature, including Jolliffe's seat. The party again became the Official Opposition after the [[Ontario general election, 1948|1948 general election]], and defeated the Conservative premier [[George A. Drew|George Drew]] in his seat, when [[William Horace Temple|Bill Temple]] unexpectedly won in the [[High Park (electoral district)|High Park]] constituency. The middle and late 1940s were the peak years for the Ontario CCF. After that time, its electoral performances were dismal, as it was reduced to a rump of two seats in the [[Ontario general election, 1951|1951 election]], three seats in the [[Ontario general election, 1955|1955 election]], and five seats in the [[Ontario general election, 1959|1959 election]]. Jolliffe stepped down as leader in 1953, and was replaced by [[Donald C. MacDonald]]. The period between the 1951 defeat and the founding of the [[Ontario New Democratic Party]] was one of much internal strife, but MacDonald managed to keep the party together, despite the constant electoral defeats. In October 1961, the party dissolved itself and became part of the New Democratic Party. ==Origins== The Ontario CCF was indirectly the successor to the 1919–23 [[United Farmers of Ontario]]–[[Labour Party of Canada|Labour]] [[coalition government|coalition]] that formed the government in Ontario under [[Ernest C. Drury]].{{cite web|last=MacPherson|first=Ian|title=The United Farmers of Ontario|url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/united-farmers-of-canada/|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|publisher=The Historica-Dominion Institute|accessdate=2011-08-16|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60zJ4VQS6?url=http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0008229|archivedate=2011-08-16|location=Toronto|year=2011|deadurl=no|df=}} While United Farmer [[Member of the Legislative Assembly|Members of the Legislative Assembly]] (MLAs) joined the [[Ontario Liberal Party]], the United Farmers of Ontario (UFO), as an organization, participated in the formation of the Ontario CCF, and was briefly affiliated with the party. After a meeting in Ottawa on May 26, 1932, that brought together all the Members of Parliament that belonged to the Ginger Group, and some members of the [[League for Social Reconstruction]] (LSR), the CCF was formed, making [[J. S. Woodsworth]] the de facto leader, and giving responsibility for organizing Ontario to [[Agnes Macphail]] of the UFO.McNaught (1959), pp.259, 262 Macphail, as president of the Ontario Provincial Council, persuaded her fellow delegates at the December 1932 UFO convention to affiliate with the CCF provincial council. After the 1933 Regina convention, the name of the party was introduced as the Co-operative Commonwealth Federation (Ontario Section) – The Farmer-Labor Party, though the shorter Ontario CCF was the most commonly used name.Szmigielski (1977), p. 232 Macphail served as the first chairman of the Ontario CCF from 1932 until 1934.Stewart & Shackelton (1959), pp. 171-172 As a UFO Member of Parliament (MP) in the Canadian House of Commons, she was forced to resign from the CCF after the UFO withdrew from the party after alleging communist influence in it.Stewart & Shackelton (1959), p. 178 Consequently, the UFO's two candidates in the [[Ontario general election, 1934|1934 provincial election]], including longtime MLA [[Farquhar Oliver]], ran under the UFO banner rather than with the CCF. Oliver was elected and later joined the Liberals. Macphail later served in the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]] as the CCF [[Member of Provincial Parliament (Ontario)|Member of Provincial Parliament]] (MPP)In 1938, Members of the Ontario Legislative Assembly (MLAs) passed a motion to adopt the title "Members of Provincial Parliament" (MPP). for [[York East]] from 1943 to 1945 and again from 1948 to 1951.{{cite web|last=Black|first=Naomi|title=Macphail, Agnes Campbell|url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/agnes-macphail/|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|publisher=The Historica-Dominion Institute|accessdate=2011-08-16|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60zge6Is7?url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0005013|archivedate=2011-08-17|location=Toronto|year=2011|deadurl=no|df=}} [[Samuel Lawrence]], an Independent Labour Party member of Hamilton City Council, was elected to the Ontario legislature as a CCF MPP in the [[Ontario general election, 1934|1934 provincial election]], the first Ontario election contested by the CCF. The party received 7.1 percent of the vote and, with Lawrence's election in [[Hamilton East (provincial electoral district)|Hamilton East]], won its first seat in the Ontario Legislature. The Ontario CCF failed to win any seats in the [[Ontario general election, 1937|1937 election]]. He was elected Ontario CCF president in 1941.{{cite news|title=SAM LAWRENCE NAMED BY C.C.F.: Unanimously Selected to Head Ontario Group|work=The Globe and Mail|date=14 April 1941}} and served as Mayor of Hamilton from 1944 to 1949 leading a CCF slate in that city. Alderman John Mitchell of Hamilton was elected the first Ontario CCF president in 1934 as part of a reorganization of the party after its provincial council had been suspended by federal leader [[J. S. Woodsworth]] for suspected communist infiltration. The reorganization created a new provincial council and central party executive and centralized what had been a loose structure of affiliate organizations and riding clubs. It was accompanied by a purge of party clubs and affiliates suspected of having been infiltrated by [[Communist Party of Canada|Communists]] and the removal of suspected Communists from senior party positions. The reorganization was prompted by complaints of Communist infiltration, due to the party's previously loose structure. In reaction to alleged Communist involvement, the United Farmers of Ontario disaffiliated from the CCF. Mitchell unofficially led the Ontario CCF during the [[Ontario general election, 1934|1934]] and conducted a province-wide tour ding the [[Ontario general election, 1937|1937 election campaign]] but failed to win a seat in the Legislature. He continued as party president until 1941.{{cite news|title=CCF Ousts Communists Welcomes Agnes MacPhail - Woodsworth Charge Government Spies Within Ranks At Housecleaning - Mitchell New Head|work=Toronto Daily Star|date=16 April 1934}}{{cite news|title=Total of 266 Candidates Nominated for Oct. 6 Ontario Election: 86 Liberals in Fight And 89 Conservatives; Others of Varied Hue Nominees in Four Ridings Not Being Contested by Party in Power Regarded as Friendly TWO WOMEN RUNNING|work=The Globe and Mail|date=30 September 1937}}{{cite news|title=Leader of CCF in Ontario raps Hepburn and Rowe|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19370917&id=pfMuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5dsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5926,5291071&hl=en|accessdate=7 February 2016|work=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|date=17 September 1937}}{{cite news|title=C.C.F. DECIDES TO EXPEL ALL COMMUNISTS: Member Who Co-operates With Communist Party Faces Expulsion From Ontario Branch of C.C.F STORMY CONVENTION|work=The Globe and Mail|date=10 April 1939}} [[Graham Spry]], a publisher and broadcaster who was also a member of the LSR, served as the Ontario CCF's vice-president of its provincial council from 1934 to 1936.Horn, p. 64 He was the first federal CCF candidate in Ontario, running in the September 24, 1934 by-election in [[Toronto East]].Horn, p. 64 Other prominent members were [[Elmore Philpott]], a former [[Ontario Liberal Party|Liberal]]. Philpott joined the CCF in 1933 and became president of the Ontario Association of CCF Clubs but resigned in March 1934 over the [[Albert Edward Smith|A. E. Smith]] affair that had caused the UFO to leave as well. Philpott rejoined the Liberal Party in 1935.{{cite news|title=C.C.F. Ontario Provincial Council Suspended: U.F.O. Withdraws And Will Stay Out; Philpott Resigns Agnes Macphail Retires Automatically as Her Repre sentative Capacity in Organization Ceases-- Woodsworth Calls for Reorganization Which Will Rid Federation of Communist Influence-- Statement Issued by Farmers' Secretary POLITICAL LABOR MOVEMENT NOW PLANNED WITHIN C.C.F.|work=The Globe|date=12 March 1934}}Young (1969), p. 145 The disagreement was in regards to how much support the fledgling CCF should give Smith, leader of the [[Canadian Labour Defence League]], who had been charged with sedition for claiming that the state had attempted to assassinate imprisoned [[Communist Party of Canada]] leader [[Tim Buck]].McNaught (1959), p. 266 The CLDC was a [[communist front]] group. Woodsworth, and the Ontario CCF provincial council, opposed the CCF having any formal links with it or any other communist group. Some individual CCFers ignored this policy as did one section of the Ontario CCF, which was expelled. Nevertheless, Philpott and the UFO saw the Smith affair as evidence that the CCF had been infiltrated by Communists and left.Crowley & Crowley (1990), p. 127 The issue of what relationship the CCF should have with the Communist Party came to the fore again in 1936 when the party voted to ban any [[united front]] with Communists, over the objections of prominent CCFers such as [[East York, Ontario|East York]] [[Reeve (Canada)|reeve]] [[Arthur Henry Williams]]. ==Breakthrough== [[Image:Ted jolliffe 1942.jpg|thumb|[[Ted Jolliffe]], CCF Leader 1942–1953]]At the Ontario CCF's tenth annual convention in Toronto, the first leadership election was held. {{cite news | title = Leader Elected: E. B. Joliffe is chosen for Ontario C.C.F. | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bhdlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7m4NAAAAIBAJ&dq=edward%20jolliffe&pg=4579%2C3294045 | accessdate = 2011-08-21 | newspaper = The Saskatoon Star-Phoenix | date = 1942-04-04 | author = The Canadian Press | location = Saskatoon, Saskatchewan }} Two candidates came forward: Toronto lawyer and Ontario CCF vice-president [[Ted Jolliffe]], and union activist and former Ontario CCF Youth Movement organizer [[Murray Cotterill]]. On April 4, 1942, Jolliffe won the election, but the voting results were not announced. The newly created Leader position's role was political and legislative, while internal CCF affairs and administration would remain the president's domain. The party achieved a major breakthrough under Jolliffe, in the [[Ontario general election, 1943|1943 general election]], when it formed the [[Leader of the Opposition (Ontario)|Official Opposition]] with 32 percent of the vote and 34 seats. The CCF was just four seats short of [[George A. Drew|George Drew]]'s [[Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario|Progressive Conservatives]] ("Tories"), who formed a [[minority government]] that was the beginning of what became a 42-year political dynasty. ==1945 "Gestapo" campaign== In the [[Ontario general election, 1945|1945 election]], Premier Drew ran an [[anti-Semitic]], union bashing, [[Red-baiting]] campaign.{{sfnp|MacDonald|1998| pp = 291–297}} The previous two years of anti-socialist attacks by the Conservatives and their supporters, like Gladstone Murray and Montague A. Sanderson, were devastatingly effective against the previously popular CCF.{{sfnp|Caplan|1973| p=157}} Much of the source material for the anti-CCF campaign came from the [[Ontario Provincial Police]] (OPP)'s Special Investigation Branch's agent D-208: Captain William J. Osbourne-Dempster. {{cite news | title = Dempster explains report inaccuracies | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vx8_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=qE8MAAAAIBAJ&dq=edward%20jolliffe&pg=6383%2C93659 | accessdate = 2011-08-21 | newspaper = The Windsor Daily Star | date = 1945-07-07 | author = The Canadian Press | location = Windsor, Ontario | page = 12 }} His office was supposed to be investigating war-time [[5th column]] saboteurs. Instead, starting in November 1943, he was investigating, almost exclusively, Ontario opposition MPPs, mainly focusing on the CCF [[caucus]].{{sfnp|Caplan | 1973 | pp = 182-184,187}} The fact that Jolliffe knew about these 'secret' investigations as early as February 1944 led to one of the most infamous incidents in 20th-century Canadian politics.{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | p=168}} ===May 24, 1945 radio speech=== The 1945 campaign was anything but genteel and polite. Jolliffe replied by giving a radio speech – written with the assistance of [[Lister Sinclair]] –{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | p=179}} that accused Drew of running a political [[Gestapo]] in Ontario.{{sfnp|MacDonald|1998| pp = 291–297}} In the speech excerpt below, Jolliffe alleged that a secret department of the [[Ontario Provincial Police]] was acting as a political police – spying on the opposition and the media.{{sfnp|MacDonald|1998| p = 292}} {{cquote|It is my duty to tell you that Colonel Drew is maintaining in Ontario, at this very minute, a secret political police, a paid government spy organization, a Gestapo to try and keep himself in power. And Col[onel] Drew maintains his secret political police at the expense of the taxpayers of Ontario – paid out of the Public Funds....{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | p=168}}}} Jolliffe's inflammatory speech became the main issue of the campaign, and dominated coverage in the media for the rest of the election.{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | p = 170}} Drew, and his [[Attorney-General of Ontario|Attorney-General]] [[Leslie Blackwell]] vehemently denied Jolliffe's accusations, but the public outcry was too much for them to abate. On May 26, 1945, during his own radio speech, Drew announced that he would be appointing a Royal Commission to investigate these charges. {{cite news | title = Drew Orders Judicial Probe Into 'Gestapo' Charges, Which He Denies | newspaper = [[The Globe and Mail]] | date = 1945-05-28 | location = Toronto | page = 8 }} Jolliffe's CCF and [[Mitchell Hepburn]]'s Ontario Liberal Party wanted the election suspended until the commission tabled its report. Hepburn sent Drew a personal telegram stating he would stop campaigning if the commission were held immediately. {{cite news | title = Probe Before Voting Hepburn tells Drew | newspaper = The Toronto Daily Star | date = 1945-05-29 | author = Special to the Star | location = Toronto | page = 4 }} Drew ignored these requests and continued to hold the election on its original date, despite it being many months before the commission's findings would be made available.{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | pp = 170-171}} ===Election Day, June 4, 1945=== Jolliffe's CCF went from 34 seats to 8, but almost garnered the same number of votes cast, though their percentage of the popular vote dropped from 32 to 22 percent.{{sfnp| Caplan | 1973 | p = 191}} A Gallup poll done a month earlier showed the CCF at essentially the same percentage, making it questionable whether or not the "Gestapo" speech had an effect on the campaign.{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | p = 171}} Drew, with his attack campaign, successfully drove the voter turn-out up, thereby driving the CCF's percentage and seat totals down. 1945 was one of Ontario's most important elections in the 20th century according to Caplan and [[David Lewis (politician)|David Lewis]].{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | p = 191}} It shaped the province for the next 40 years, as the Conservatives won a massive majority in the Legislature, and would remain in government for the next 40 consecutive years–most of that time with majority governments until the mid-1970s. For Jolliffe, another election consequence was his tenure as the MPP from York South ended, at least for the time-being. He lost the election but did better than any other CCF candidate in Toronto or in the outlying Yorks.{{sfnp| Caplan | 1973 | p = 191}} ===LeBel Royal Commission=== On May 28, Drew appointed Justice A.M. LeBel as the [[Royal Commissioner]], thereby forming what has become known as the [[LeBel Royal Commission]]. His terms of reference were restricted to the question of whether Drew was personally responsible for the establishment of "a secret political police organization, for the purpose of collecting, by secret spying, material to be used in attempt to keep him in power."{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | pp = 171-172}} Wider questions like why the OPP, Ontario civil servants, were keeping files on MPPs were not allowed. Jolliffe acted as his own counsel throughout the commission, but was assisted by fellow CCF lawyer, [[Andrew Brewin]]. {{cite news | title = Jolliffe Protests Probe Into How He Obtained Confidential Police Data | newspaper = The Globe and Mail | date = 1945-06-21 | author = Globe staff | location = Toronto | page = 3 }} He and Brewin were able to establish, from several eyewitnesses, that agent D-208, Dempster, was spying on the CCF. What they could not prove, because they did not have access to the information in 1945,{{sfnp | Lewis | 1981 | p = 276}} were the letters that Drew wrote to his supporter M.A. (Bugsy) Sanderson suggesting that he would finance any lawsuits or other charges stemming from the information provided by Dempster in his advertisements.{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | p = 173}} Sanderson was, in late 1943 to 1945, along with Gladstone Murray, leading the libellous advertisement campaigns against the CCF in newspapers and billboards, with information gleaned from Dempster's briefings.{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | pp = 172-188}} Jolliffe presented several witnesses that claimed to have seen these documents. But Jolliffe could not produce the letter, and Drew denied ever writing it.{{sfnp | Caplan | 1973 | pp = 172-188}} On October 11, 1945, Justice LeBel issued his report that essentially exonerated Drew and Blackwell. {{ cite news | title = Premier Drew and his government absolved of forming "Gestapo" | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0iQzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BtwFAAAAIBAJ&dq=ontario%20premier%20knew%20about%20secret%20police&pg=6246%2C2175834 | accessdate = 2016-02-16 | newspaper = The Evening Citizen | date = 1945-10-12 | author = The Canadian Press | location = Ottawa | page = 13 }} Because Jolliffe presented only circumstantial evidence that linked Drew to Dempster, Murray and Sanderson, the Commissioner found the information unconvincing, even though LeBel believed Dempster's interaction with Sanderson and Murray was inappropriate.{{sfn | Caplan | 1973 |pp = 181-188}} Jolliffe's motives regarding his accusations, and his choice of words, were questioned for many years afterwards. In the late 1970s, when [[David Lewis (politician)|David Lewis]] was doing research for his ''Memoirs'', he came across archival evidence proving the charge. {{cite news | title = Former Ontario premier 'knew of police spy unit' | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-xciAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KKUFAAAAIBAJ&dq=ted%20jolliffe&pg=2008%2C1144086 | accessdate = 2011-08-21 | newspaper = The Montreal Gazette | date = 1981-12-03 | author = UPC }} Because of Lewis's discovery, Drew's son Edward, placed extremely restrictive conditions on his father's papers housed in the [[Library and Archives Canada|Public Archives of Canada]].{{sfnp | MacDonald | 1998 | p = 295-296}}{{refn|group="Note"|When Edward Drew (George's son) dies, these archives will become unrestricted. {{cite web | title = George Drew fonds: Call# MG 32-C3 | work = Restricted Papers | publisher = [[Library and Archives Canada]] | date = 2005-01-04 | url = http://data2.archives.ca/pdf/pdf001/r000000841.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2007-05-13}}}} As Lewis pointed out in his memoirs, "We found that Premier Drew and Gladstone Murray did not disclose all information to the Lebel Commission; indeed, they deliberately prevaricated throughout. The head of the [[Politics of Ontario|Government of Ontario]] had given false witness under testimony.... The perpetrator of Ontario's [[Watergate scandal|Watergate]] got away with it."{{sfnp | Lewis | 1981 | pp = 276, 287}} ==1945 election aftermath== After the LeBel Report was published, the Ontario CCF still had to go on with the business of running the party, and hold its annual convention.Young (1969), pp. 117–118 It had been over 18 months since the previous provincial convention was held.{{cite news|title=Jolliffe is standing for C.C.F. leadership|newspaper=The Toronto Daily Star|date=1945-11-20|author=Star Staff|location=Toronto|page=7}} The convention was held from Thursday, November 22, to Saturday, November 24 at the Toronto Labor Lyceum on Spadina Avenue. Jolliffe made it publicly known before the convention that he intended to continue as leader. He ran despite the elements within the party that blamed him for the election defeat. His critics charged that the CCF did not stress policy enough during the election; that the party's platform was too vague, too leader-based, and was too reliant on slogans. Jolliffe was attacked for how he handled the last weeks of the campaign, especially over the "Gestapo" speech. These critics also blamed labour's involvement in dumbing-down the campaign, which was seen as the trade unions doing anything to achieve power. It got so bad, that a motion to expel Jolliffe, and David Lewis over these perceived grievances made it on to the convention floor. The motion read, "the campaign tactics of the 1945 election had been decided by Mr. Jolliffe with the advice of Mr. Lewis and the democratic processes within the CCF had been ignored." It was defeated, but it also demonstrated that the party's establishment had angered its socialist militant base. On Saturday afternoon, after the grievances were aired, the convention unanimously passed a resolution condemning Premier Drew asking him to stop spying on labour and political officials.{{cite news|title=End political spying provincial C.C.F. asks|newspaper=The Toronto Daily Star|date=1945-11-26|author=Star Staff|page=17}} After that, the party's establishment candidates held on to their positions: University of Toronto professor, [[George Grube]] remained as president, while Jolliffe remained leader.{{cite news|title=Drew flouting 48-hour order is C.C.F. charge|newspaper=The Toronto Daily Star|date=1945-11-26|author=Star Staff|location=Toronto|page=17}} In 1946, there was major labour strife in Ontario, and the CCF made it clear they were on the side of the unionists.{{cite news|title=Jolliffe sees Ottawa vote in 18 months: C.C.F. meeting hears provincial election is possible in 1948|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qiY_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XE8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=6634%2C2218128|accessdate=2011-08-21|newspaper=The Windsor Daily Star|date=1946-12-10|author=The Canadian Press|page=16}} The party's annual convention was held outside of Toronto for the first time.{{cite news|title=C.C.F. Convention|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_yE_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=vE8MAAAAIBAJ&dq=ccf%20convention%20hamilton&pg=6616%2C3469295|accessdate=2011-08-21|newspaper=The Windsor Star|date=1946-11-22|author=Star Staff|location=Windsor, Ontario|page=11}} The convention was held at the Royal Connaught Hotel in [[Hamilton, Ontario]] from December 9–11, 1946, the city where the [[United Steelworkers|United Steelworkers of America]] (USWA) went through a long protracted strike about reducing the work-week to 40 hours.{{cite news|title=Labor won, despite tricks by Capitalists–Jolliffe|newspaper=The Toronto Daily Star|date=1946-12-10|author=Special to The Star|location=Toronto|page=3}} Jolliffe faced a leadership challenge at this convention from former Toronto [[Toronto Board of Control|Control]]ler [[Lewis Duncan]].{{cite news|title=C.C.F. asks liquor votes|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rCY_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XE8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=3849%2C2860313|accessdate=2011-08-21|newspaper=The Windsor Daily Star|date=1946-12-12|author=Star Staff|location=Windsor, Ontario|page=19}} There were rumblings in 1945 that Duncan would take over from Jolliffe, but that was rumoured to be only if he were able to defeat Drew in the High Park constituency, which he failed to do.{{cite news|title=Says Jolliffe to keep helm: Duncan denies C.C.F. to change leaders|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0CM_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=-U8MAAAAIBAJ&dq=jolliffe%20and%20duncan&pg=3153%2C3724985|accessdate=2011-08-21|newspaper=The Windsor Daily Star|date=1945-04-23|author=Star Staff|location=Windsor, Ontario|page=13}}{{cite news|title=Servicemen's vote brings extra seat to Ontario Liberals|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wsY6AAAAIBAJ&sjid=SyoMAAAAIBAJ&dq=jolliffe%20and%20duncan&pg=2270%2C15014664|accessdate=2011-08-21|newspaper=The Maple Leaf|date=1945-06-27|author=The Canadian Press|location=London, England|page=3}} As party chairman John Mitchell stated at the time, it wasn't even close, as Jolliffe was easily re-elected CCF leader again for the fourth time. Professor Grube stepped down as the president, and Andrew Brewin succeeded him after defeating former [[York South]] MP, [[Joseph W. Noseworthy]] by four votes. The main resolution that would affect the upcoming provincial election was one that condemned Drew's government for its hastily approved legislation allowing for cocktail bars to operate in Ontario. ==1948 Ontario general election== Though the [[Ontario general election, 1948|1948 election]] came about a year sooner than normal, the Ontario CCF had been expecting this because of the polling information available that indicated that Drew's popularity was falling.{{cite news|title=Jolliffe sees Ottawa vote in 18 months: C.C.F. meeting hears provincial election is possible in 1948|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qiY_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XE8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=6634%2C2218128|accessdate=2011-08-22|newspaper=The Windsor Daily Star|date=1946-12-10|author=The Canadian Press|location=Windsor, Ontario|page=16}} The CCF were able to rebound from their previous dismal election performance in 1945, and this time managed to get 21 members elected, including Jolliffe in York South, to again form the Official Opposition. The real surprise was that Premier Drew lost his seat, even though his Progressive Conservatives won a majority. In his High Park constituency, Drew was up against his local nemesis [[William Horace Temple|William (Bill) Temple]]. Temple was a [[Temperance movement|temperance]] campaigner and made Drew's cocktail bar legislation the main campaign issue.Melnyk, pp. 177-178 Temple castigated Drew for softening Ontario's liquor laws, claiming the Premier was the captive of "liquor interests" because of the government's decision to allow liquor sales in cocktail bars. While Drew's party swept to victory across the province, Drew was defeated by Temple, and decided to resign as premier and move to federal politics.{{cite news|title=Premier losses in High Park, CCF Wins 11 Area Seats|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=1948-06-08|author=Canadian Press|location=Toronto|page=1}} ==1951 election disaster and its aftermath== The CCF's return to popularity was short-lived because of the prosperity of the 1950s and the [[Anti-communism|anti-Communist]] hysteria of the [[Cold War]]. This rapid decline in their popularity reduced the party to two seats in the [[Ontario general election, 1951|1951 election]] and allowed the [[Ontario Liberal Party]] to become the Official Opposition. No social democratic party would be the Official Opposition again until [[Ontario general election, 1975|1975]], when Stephen Lewis's NDP displaced the Liberals as the second party in the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]]. Beginning with the 1951 provincial campaign, the [[Ontario Federation of Labour]] (OFL) played an increased role in the Ontario CCF by lending it organizational, personnel and material support.Azoulay (1999), pp. 33–36 The increasing role of the trade union leadership in the party was unpopular with some activists like MPP Bill Temple. The "Ginger Group" led by Temple, [[True Davidson]] and others was formed in the wake of the disastrous 1951 electoral result which they blamed on the "bureaucratization" of the party and its movement away from socialist principles and particularly socialist education, developments for which they held what they saw as the conservative, anti-democratic and bureaucratic influence of the OFL as responsible. At the party's 1952 convention, Temple ran for party leader but withdrew at the last moment, allowing Jolliffe to be acclaimed leader.Azoulay (1999), p. 40{{cite news|title=CCF Split Buried as Temple Loses Vote|newspaper=The Toronto Star|date=1952-04-12|author=Star staff|location=Toronto|pages=1–2}} Temple did not stop from making trouble for the establishment, when he ran for party president, and almost won. He and Davidson were elected to the party executive as vice-presidents and the Ginger Group elected a number of its followers to the provincial council. They were unsuccessful in achieving their goals, however. The increasing role of the OFL in the Ontario CCF proved to be a precursor to the eventual fusion of the national CCF and the trade union movement with the creation of the [[New Democratic Party of Canada]] at the federal and provincial levels in 1961. ==End of the CCF/New Party and revival== [[Image:Donald c. macdonald speaking.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Donald C. MacDonald]], CCF/NDP Leader from 1953 to 1970. Seen here in February 2007]][[Donald C. MacDonald]] became leader in 1953,{{cite news|last=McNenly|first=Pat|title=New Party Spurns CCF 'Tory' Setup|newspaper=Toronto Daily Star|date=1961-10-07|location=Toronto|pages=1, 14}} and spent the next years rebuilding the party, from two seats when he took over the party's helm, to three in his first election and then five in 1959. Delegates from the Ontario CCF, delegates from affiliated union locals, and delegates from New Party Clubs took part in the founding convention of the New Democratic Party of Ontario held in Niagara Falls at the Sheraton Brock Hotel from 7–9 October 1961 and elected MacDonald as their leader.{{cite news|author=Star Staff|title=New Party Drafts Plan for Ontario|newspaper=The Toronto Star|date=1961-09-21|page=01|location=Toronto}} The Ontario CCF Council ceased to exist on Sunday, 8 October 1961, when the newly elected NDP executive officially took over. The rebuilding process continued under Macdonald who led a 20-person caucus by the time he stepped down in 1970. ==Election results== {| class="wikitable" !Election !Leader !Seats !Change +/- !Votes !Percentage !Standing !Legislative role !Government |- ![[Ontario general election, 1934|1934]] |align="left" rowspan=2|John Mitchell

MacDonald]] |align=left|{{Composition bar|3|98|hex={{Canadian party colour|AB|CCF}}}} |{{increase}} 1 |align=center|n.a. |align=center|16.5% |{{steady}} 3rd |{{no2|Third party}} |- ![[Ontario general election, 1959|1959]] |align=left|{{Composition bar|5|98|hex={{Canadian party colour|AB|CCF}}}} |{{increase}} 2 |align=center|n.a. |align=center|16.7% |{{steady}} 3rd |{{no2|Third party}} |} ==Leaders== {{see also|Ontario CCF/NDP leadership elections }} There was no party leader prior to 1942. From 1932 to 1934 [[Agnes Macphail]], as chair of the Ontario CCF provincial council, was the main co-spokesperson. Her other co-spokesperson was [[Elmore Philpott]] – from 1933 to 1934 – as president of the Ontario Association of CCF Clubs. They were the most prominent figures in the Ontario party and acted as spokespersons until their March 1934 resignations.{{cite news | title = CCF Ousts Communists Welcomes Agnes Macphail - Woodsworth Charge Government Spies Within Ranks At Housecleaning - Mitchell New Head | work = Toronto Daily Star | date = 16 April 1934 | page = }} From 1934 to 1942 the new position of Ontario CCF president was the party's effective leader. Ontario CCF president John Mitchell, a Hamilton alderman, led the party's campaigns in the [[Ontario general election, 1934|1934]] and [[Ontario general election, 1937|1937 Ontario elections]]. {{cite news | title = Leader of CCF in Ontario raps Hepburn and Rowe | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2194&dat=19370917&id=pfMuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5dsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5926,5291071&hl=en | accessdate = 7 February 2016 | work = Ottawa Citizen | date = 17 September 1937 | page = 16 }} {{cite news | title = Total of 266 Candidates Nominated for Oct. 6 Ontario Election: 86 Liberals in Fight And 89 Conservatives; Others of Varied Hue Nominees in Four Ridings Not Being Contested by Party in Power Regarded as Friendly TWO WOMEN RUNNING | work = Globe and Mail | date = 30 September 1937 | page = 1 | location = Toronto }} {{cite news | title = 266 to Contest Ontario Seats | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19370930&id=pYAtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QJkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4407,3965980&hl=en | accessdate = 7 February 2016 | work = Montreal Gazette | date = 30 September 1937 | page = 1 }} From 1934 to 1937 [[Samuel Lawrence]], MPP for [[Hamilton East (provincial electoral district)|Hamilton East]] led the party in the legislature as its sole MPP. The '''Convention of Royal Burghs''', more fully termed the '''Convention of the Royal Burghs of Scotland''', was a representative assembly which protected the privileges and pursued the interests of Scotland’s principal trading towns, the [[royal burghs]], from the middle of the 16th century to the second half of the 20th century.Donaldson and Morpeth 1992 p.31 It evolved as a forum in which [[burgh]] delegates, termed "commissioners", could "consult together and take common action in matters concerning their common welfare"W.O. 1899 p.1 before and during the sittings of [[Parliament of Scotland|parliament]].Macdonald 2007 p.59 An exclusively merchant body, it was essentially a parliament which "declared the law of the burghs" just as the Scottish Parliament "declared the law of the land".Dickinson 1961, p.186 The Convention expanded over time by admitting [[Burgh of barony|lesser burghs]] to its membership;Mackie et al. 1978, p.107 and by the 16th century had grown in influence to the extent that "it was listened to rather than directed by the government".{{cite book |first=J |last=Wormald |title=Court, Kirk and Community |publisher=Edward Arnold |location=London |date=1981 |page=174}} Though still known as the "convention of royal burghs", it referred to itself from the late 17th century onwards as simply the "convention of burghs", as by then membership was no longer restricted exclusively to royal burghs and commissioners from all types of burgh were represented in parliament.Macdonald 2007 p.20 == Origin == The mediaeval roots of the Convention lay in the 13th-century '''Court of the Four Burghs''' which comprised delegates from [[Berwick-upon-Tweed|Berwick]], [[Edinburgh]], [[Roxburgh]] and [[Stirling]]. (In 1369 [[Lanark]] and [[Linlithgow]] replaced Berwick and Roxburgh after these came under English occupation.)Donaldson and Morpeth 1992 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}}Donaldson 1980 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}} Representatives of these burghs met in advance of parliamentary sittings and communicated with the [[Monarch|sovereign]] through the Court or through the [[Chamberlain (office)|Chamberlain]] who presided over its meetings in his function as the Crown’s chief fiscal officer. The Court, described in a charter from the reign of [[James II of Scotland|James II (1430-60)]] as the '''Parliament of the Four Burghs''',Donaldson and Morpeth 1992 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}} determined burghal law (''leges burgorum''), settled inter-burghal disputes and heard appeals from burgh courts.Dickinson 1961 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}} The earliest record of its deliberations dates from 1292 when "the four burghs" were asked to interpret the law on a question of debt.Dickinson 1961, p.119 The Court applied a single set of rules and its decisions were binding on all royal burghs.{{#tag:ref|Mackay gives the 16 original royal burghs in the reign of David I as Aberdeen, Dumfries, Edinburgh, Forfar, Haddington, Inverkeithing, Jedburgh, Lanark, Linlithgow, Montrose, Peebles, Perth, Rutherglen, St. Andrews, Selkirk, Stirling.Mackay 1884, p.2|group="n"}}Macdonald 2007 p.5 The evolution of burgh representation in relation to the history of the [[Parliament of Scotland|Scottish Parliament]] was a long and gradual process, the record of which has been to a large extent obscured by the loss of Scotland's national records at various times in the country's history.{{cite web |url=http://www.nas.gov.uk/about/history.asp |title=History of the National Archives of Scotland|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |work=The National Archives of Scotland |publisher= |accessdate=February 15, 2013}} The fragmentary nature of the surviving evidence makes it difficult to give a precise chronology of the development.Macdonald 2007 p.6 As the main source of [[Coins|specie]] in the kingdomMacdonald 2007, p.15 the burghs were specially summoned by royal letters to convene at the sittings of parliament.Rait 1924 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}} The traditionally accepted date for the first occasion of their being present is 1326, when they were summoned to appear at the parliament of [[Robert I of Scotland|Robert I]] held at [[Cambuskenneth Abbey|Cambuskenneth]].Rait 1924, p.239 The reason appears to have been the King's need to restore damage done to the royal [[demesne]]s during the [[Scottish Wars of Independence|Wars of Independence]],R L Mackie, A Short History Of Scotland, Oliver & Boyd 1962, p.85 It is not, however, clear whether the burgesses sat alongside the bishops and barons as a separate estate within the parliament itself.Rait 1924, p.240 [[File:Scotland Groat ca 1329-1370.jpg|thumb|160px|A groat from the reign of David II in the 14th century. Burghs were expected to pay their taxes in coin.]] When taxation had to be raised to pay the ransom for the release of [[David II of Scotland|David II]] from English captivity,Rait 1924, p.243 the burghs were consulted again at Scone in 1357 and empowered to negotiate the release. Thus, 1357 has been seen as the date for burgh commissioners establishing themselves as a political class within the parliament, indicated by the first use of the term "three estates (''tres communitates'') of the realm" to describe the parliament's composition. Nicholson 1989, p.166 The burghs were consulted again at the parliament held in [[Stirling]] in 1405 when 50,000 merks had to be raised for "the King's fynance", to meet [[Henry VI of England|Henry VI]]'s demand for "expenses incurred" by [[James I of Scotland|James I]] during his long imprisonment in England. Mackay 1884, p.16Rait 1924 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}} For this session it was decided that two or three commissioners from every burgh south of the [[River Spey|Spey]] should attend to "treat, ordain and determine upon all things concerning the utility of the common weal of all the King’s burghs".Dickinson 1961, p.186 Historians have therefore judged 1405 as the true date for the start of the Convention,Nicholson 1989, p.264 which met at every session of parliament from that time onwards. The "Court of Four" continued to function until 1529, "the provost of the burgh where the meeting was held acting as president", though the Chamberlain still attended Mackay 1884, p.6 (his involvement ended formally in 1532).Macdonald 2007 p.7 == Reign of James III == [[File:James III of Scotland.jpg|thumb|left|upright|160px|King James III]]The growing importance of the Convention can be traced through the reign of [[James III of Scotland|James III (r.1460-88)]] when the burghs contributed one fifth of the total sum of national taxation granted by Parliament. From 1455 onwards, Parliament was attended on average by 16 burghs, rising to 22 in 1469, 23 in 1471 and 33 by the end of the reign in 1488.Mackie and Pryde 1923, p.4 Geographical representation also widened and meetings became more frequent. An Act of Parliament in 1487 ordained that commissioners of all burghs should meet annually to deal with matters of common concern.Donaldson 1980, p.101
...that Commissioners of all Burrowes baith south and north [of the [[River Spey|Spey]]], sall convene and gadder together aince ilk yeare [annually] in the Burche of Inverkeithin [burgh of [[Inverkeithing]]], on the morning eftir Sanct James daie, with full commissioune, and thair to commune and treate upoune the weilfare of merchandise, the gude rule and statutis for the common profite of the Burrowis, and to provide for remeid upoune the skaith [damage] and injuries sustened, within the Burrowis, and quhat Burche that compeiris nocht [does not comply], the saides daie, be thair Commissaris, to paye to the costis of the Commissaris present, five pundis... Mackay 1884, p.5
== 16th Century == By the time more or less continuous{{#tag:ref|A gap exists for 1631–49 when the records were lost or destroyed "during the troubilsum tymes" of the [[Wars of the Covenant]].|group="n"}} records begin in the middle of the 16th century (1552),Mackay 1884, p.6, the Convention met regularly as a separate assembly to decide on a common policy for adoption by Parliament.Donaldson and Morpeth 1992 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}}Dickinson 1961 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}} The editor of its Records, Sir James Marwick, relates that the Convention was summoned by royal letters in 1529, 1530–31, 1539 and 1556.Mackie and Pryde 1923, p.3 Records from the regency of [[Mary of Guise]] suggest that the burghs themselves fixed the date and place of their conventions, a practice later confirmed by statute in 1581.Macdonald 2007 p.8 In 1563 they gained the right to be consulted on "peace and war" and, from 1567, on "weighty affairs" of the realm.Dickinson 1961 {{page number needed|date=May 2018}} In 1578 [[James VI of Scotland|James VI]] authorised them to meet "foure tymes in the yeare for sic materis as concerns thair Estait, and in quhatever Burche it sal be thocht expedient. Annual records of the Convention begin in that year.Donaldson and Morpeth 1992 p.46 Marwick summarised the Convention’s functions thus, [[File:Blaeu 1652 - Veere.jpg|thumb|[[Willem Blaeu|Blaeu]] map of [[Veere]], Scotland's staple port in Flanders from 1541 to 1799]]
Scarcely anything affecting Burghs of Scotland, in their internal administration, or in their commercial relations at home and abroad, escaped the cognizance of the Convention. It defined the rights, privileges and duties of Burghs; it regulated the merchandise, manufactures and shipping of the country, it exercised control over the Scottish merchants in France, Flanders and other countries in Europe, with which from time to time commercial relations existed; it sent commissioners to foreign powers, and to great commercial communities, entered into treaties with them, and established the staple trade of Scotland wherever this could be most advantageously done: it claimed the right, independently of the Crown, to nominate the Conservator [official charged with safeguarding the privileges of the Scottish [[The Staple|staple]] in Flanders]. And it certainly did regulate his emoluments, and control his conduct; it sometimes defrayed, and sometimes contributed towards, the expenses of ambassadors from the Scottish Court to that of France and other foreign powers in matters affecting the Burghs and the common weal; it allocated among the whole Burghs of the Kingdom their proportion of all extents and taxes granted by the three Estates of the realm; it adjudicated on the claims of Burghs to be admitted to the privileges of free Burghs, and to be added to its roll; it took cognizance of weights and measures." Rait 1924, pp.12-13
(The agreed weights and measures were based on the "stane wecht" [stone weight] of [[Lanark]], the "pint stoupe" [liquid measure] of [[Stirling]], the "firlatt" [quarter-boll—a dry measure of meal] of [[Linlithgow]] and the "elland" [length, e.g. of cloth] of [[Edinburgh]])Mackie and Pryde 1923, p.15 == 17th Century == [[File:Downsitting of the Scottish Parliament.JPG|thumb|18thC French illustration of an opening of the Scottish Parliament. The procession is headed by ''"Les Commissaires des Comtes, et des Bourgs, et des Villes"''.]] On 21 August 1604, the Convention agreed articles for the guidance of the Scottish Commissioners appointed to negotiate arrangements under the [[Union of the Crowns]]. The first called for the upholding of [[Scots Law]], "that the inhabitants of Scotland be ruled and governed by the laws of this realme, and no way subject to any other law"; the second urged "that in the Treaty of Union nothing be touched which may prejudice the ancient liberties, privileges, immunities, infeftments [possession of heritable property], and laws, made in favour of the burghs by his Majesty and his Highnesses most noble progenitors."Mackay 1884, p.36 The relative importance of the Convention in the 17th century can be judged from a statement made by the [[Lord Advocate]], [[George Mackenzie (lawyer)|George Mackenzie of Rosehaugh]], that "The burrows of Scotland have liberty to meet in time of Parliament, and to propose as a Body and Third Estate, Overtures for Trade; but no other estate of Parliament can lawfully meet [i.e. outside Parliament], this being a singularity indulged to them for the Good of Commerce."Sir George Mackenzie of Rosehaugh, Lord Advocate, Observations on the Scots Acts of Parliament, Printed by the heir of Andrew Anderson, Edinburgh 1686. Burghs of [[Burgh of regality|regality]] or of [[Burgh of barony|barony]], hitherto excluded from participating in foreign trade, were accorded the privilege in 1672.Mackie et al. 1978, p.246 but to maintain the pre-eminent position of the royal burghs an Act of Parliament (1690) stipulated the sum to be paid by the lesser burghs to reduce the burden of taxation imposed on the royal burghs.Mackay 1884, p.50 By 1689, 70 burghs were members of the Convention,Mackie and Pryde 1923, p.6 though, according to one study, the royal burghs remained the dominant influence throughout the period: "...meetings did not always involve the whole estate suggesting that a smaller group of wealthier burghs were the driving force behind the convention in general and burghs' parliamentary agenda in particular.Macdonald 2007 p.64 == Later importance == It has been argued that the effect of the Convention was to make the burgesses historically the most organised of the three estates represented in the Scots parliament. It also "ensured that urban government was much more uniform in Scotland than in England, producing, as the commissioners' inquiry into the Municipal Corporations of Scotland discovered in 1833–1835, considerable corruption amongst self-electing, clone-like burgh establishments". The main concern of the Convention in the early part of the 19th century became "the blocking of reform. The Municipal Reform Act of 1834 sharply reduced its influence and its abolition was considered for a time. The admission to it of parliamentary burghs in 1879 and police burghs in 1895 gave it an added lease of life though probably little extra influence." {{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia=The Oxford Companion to Scottish History |editor-first=Michael |editor-last=Lynch |publisher=Oxford University Press |orig-year=2001 |date=2007 |doi=10.1093/acref/9780199234820.001.0001 |section-url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780199234820.001.0001/acref-9780199234820-e-256 |isbn=9780191727481 |article=Royal Burghs, Convention of |page=534: Burgomasters Since 1800 |first=John |last=Garrard |series=Oxford Reference |subscription=Y}} The Convention was viewed by [[Palace of Westminster|Westminster]] politicians in the late 19th century as "thoroughly representative of public opinion in Scotland" and "as giving those who have to deal with the affairs of Scotland an opportunity of feeling the pulse of Scotland".W.O. 1899 pp.4-5 quoting W E Gladstone, the Marquess of Lothian and the earl of Rosebery In 1899, it consisted of 103 burghs and 207 representativesW.O. 1899 p.6 in an organisation described by a Scottish government minister as "the oldest existing representative body in Europe".W.O. 1899 p.9, quoting Under-Secretary of Scotland R W Cochran-Patrick, Esq MP The same study observes that, "the Convention can probably lay claim to being one of the wordiest of Scottish institutions, if measured by the voluminous nature of its records. But its importance was relatively slight". The Convention was abolished when local government was regionally reorganised in 1975 in line with the recommendations of the [[Royal Commission on Local Government in Scotland|Wheatley Report]] of 1969. It was superseded by the present-day Convention of Scottish Local Authorities ([[Convention of Scottish Local Authorities|COSLA]]). {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Poland.svg|150px]]}} '''Corruption in Poland''' has declined over time in the recent years. In international rankings it is below the world average but not insignificant. Within Poland, surveys of Polish citizens reveal that it is perceived to be a major problem.
==Extent== Transparency International's 2017 Corruption Perception Index ranks the country 36th place out of 180 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2017|title=Corruption Perception Index 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> It is the eighth successive year in which Poland's score and ranking have improved in the Index.
[[Global Integrity]] 2010 report gave Poland the score of 80 out of a 100 assessing the legal framework as 86 (strong) and actual implementation as 71 (moderate).<ref name=gi/> The report scored Poland particularly well (score of 90) in categories for "Non-Governmental Organizations, Public Information and Media" and "Elections", and particularly low in the category for "Public Administration and Professionalism" (score of 59).<ref name="gi"/>
[[File:Siedziba NIK - front.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Supreme Audit Office (Poland)|Supreme Audit Office]] (NIK) offices.]] A 2011 report by the [[Institute of Public Affairs, Poland|Institute of Public Affairs]] also criticized the standards of public life in Poland, and the prevalence of [[nepotism]] and [[cronyism]].<ref name="t-isp"/>
A 2012 report jointly prepared by from the Institute of Public Affairs and [[Transparency International]] notes that the corruption in Poland is lower than in the past, when in the mid-1990s it was "a phenomenon of a systemic nature".<ref name="t-nis2012"/> As described in that report, the World Bank [[Worldwide Governance Indicators]] (accessible here [http://databank.worldbank.org/data/databases.aspx?tags=rule-of-law]) for "rule of law" and "control of corruption" show steady improvement for Poland.<ref name=t-nis2012/> Poland has joined the [[OECD Anti-Bribery Convention]] in 2000, implementing relevant legislation in 2001.<ref name="Poland:- Poland - OECD Anti-Bribery Convention - Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development"/> Poland has also made significant progress in combating corruption like the establishment of the [[Central Anti-Corruption Bureau]] and the first anti-corruption strategy which was adopted in 2002.<ref name=t-nis2012/>
The 2012 report from the ISP and TI report, reviewing individual Polish anti-corruption institution, praised the [[Supreme Audit Office (Poland)|Supreme Audit Office]] (NIK), followed by the [[Polish Ombudsman]] (RPO).<ref name=t-nis2012/> It criticized the civil society,the private sector, and the executive and public administration of insufficient efforts in fighting corruption.<ref name=t-nis2012/> Poland's watchdog organisations are considered weak in combating corruption, and corruption allegations often appear in government contracting and permit issuance.<ref name=t-isp/><ref name="Snapshot of the Poland Country Profile"/>
The 2012 report from the ISP and TI praised the overall direction of the anti-corruption efforts in Poland, noting that they are "bringing noticeable results", but noted that those efforts, particularly from the public authorities, are "rather chaotic, sometimes contradictory or even controversial". It concluded that "corruption in Poland still entails considerable risks" and "the level of anti-corruption protection is unsatisfactory".<ref name=t-nis2012/> A 2013 OECD report analyzing the implementation of the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention concluded that "the current Polish framework for fighting foreign bribery is still inadequate".<ref name="Bribery in international business - Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development"/>
A 2013 survey in Poland found that 83% of surveyed Polish citizens think that corruption is a major problem for their country, particularly prevalent among politicians (62 percent) and in the health-care sector (53 percent). A growing number of citizens (57%) is concerned that there is no political will to fight corruption.<ref name="Poles see significant corruption in Poland - Warsaw Business Journal - Online Portal"/>
==Historical== In the early 1920s, during the first years of the [[Second Polish Republic]], Polish institutions were plagued by endemic corruption,<ref name="The Eagle Unbowed: Poland and the Poles in the Second World War"/> and several of the governments of the day were accused of corruption, very likely with sound cause.<ref name="The History of Poland"/> Between 1923 and 1926, [[Józef Piłsudski]] came to conclude that the system which he dubbed "[[Sejm]]ocracy" fostered general corruption, ultimately leading him to launch the [[May Coup (Poland)|May Coup]] and seize power.<ref name="The Origins of Modern Polish Democracy"/> His byword [[Sanation]] referred to the cleansing he promised to introduce, in contrast to his predecessors' shady practices.<ref name="Genocide and Fascism: The Eliminationist Drive in Fascist Europe"/>
However, once in power, his allies uncovered very few cases of corruption in past governments; persistent references to mass corruption amounted to a type of "primitive propaganda", in the words of historian [[Andrzej Garlicki]]. Later, it was Piłsudskiites who became embroiled in a well-publicized scandal revolving around election budgets, the [[Czechowicz Affair]].<ref name="The Clash of Moral Nations: Cultural Politics in Piłsudski's Poland, 1926-1935"/> By the 1930s, the country had developed an economic model involving [[state capitalism]], with key industries in government hands. While this fostered growth in vital areas, it also gave rise to inefficiency and corruption. Private businesses found it hard to compete directly with state-owned concerns, in particular for public contracts.<ref name="A Traveller's History of Poland"/>
In the communist [[People's Republic of Poland]], corruption was widespread, particularly by [[Polish United Workers Party]] officials (''see [[nomenklatura]]'').<ref name="Bloom2013"/><ref name="ChodakiewiczRadzilowski2003"/><ref name="Old and New Patterns of Corruption in Poland and the USSR"/> Corruption under the communist regime was so pervasive that some scholars have referred to the system as "legalized corruption".<ref name="Lü2000"/>

{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of the Philippines.svg|150 px]]}} The [[Philippines]] suffers from widespread [[Political corruption|corruption]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Jurado |first=Emil |url=http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/insideOpinion.htm?f=2010/march/12/emiljurado.isx&d=2010/march/12 |title=The fourth most corrupt nation |publisher=''Manila Standard Today'' |date=March 12, 2010 |accessdate=August 21, 2010}}</ref> Means of corruption include [[Graft (politics)|graft]], [[bribery]], [[embezzlement]], [[backdoor deals]], [[nepotism]], and [[patronage]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Conde |first=Carlos |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/13/business/worldbusiness/13iht-peso.4891792.html |title=Philippines most corrupt, survey says |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=March 13, 2007 |accessdate=August 21, 2010}}</ref>
==Decline== [[Transparency International]]'s 2017 Corruption Perception Index ranks the country 111th place out of 180 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2017|title=Corruption Perception Index 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
This is better than the Philippines' 129th out of 178,ranking in 2011 with a 2.6 CPI, in Transparency International's list. The CPI score indicates the perceived level of public sector corruption on a scale of 0 - 100, where 0 means that a country is perceived as highly corrupt and 100 means that a country is perceived as very clean.
Transparency International-Philippines said some of the factors that contributed to the Philippines' (2.6) slight jump are the improvement in government service, and cutting red tape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/06/27/12/ph-corruption-going-going-not-yet-gone|title=PH corruption going, going, but not yet gone|first=By Willard Cheng, ABS-CBN|last=News|date=|website=abs-cbnnews.com}}</ref>
The Philippines' corruption further declined in 2014 upgrading its ranking on Transparency.org CPI from 94th to 85th in 2013 and 2014, respectively.
==Statistical evaluations== For the list of rankings per country per year, please see http://www.transparency.org/research/cpi/overview
==Political nepotism== {{Further|Political dynasties in the Philippines|List of political families in the Philippines}}
[[Politics of the Philippines|The Philippine political arena]] is mainly arranged and operated by [[Political dynasties in the Philippines|families or alliances of families]], rather than organised around the voting for political parties.<ref>Coronel, Chua, Rimban, & Cruz ''The Rulemakers'' [[Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism]] (2007); p.49</ref>
Called the [[Padrino System]], one gains favor, [[Promotion (rank)|promotion]], or political appointment through family affiliation ([[nepotism]]) or friendship ([[cronyism]]), as opposed to one's [[Meritocracy|merit]]. The ''Padrino System'' in the Philippines has been the source of many controversies and corruption.
It has been an [[open secret]] that one cannot join the political arena of the Philippines without mastery of the Padrino System. From the lowest [[Barangay]] official, to the [[President of the Philippines|President of the Republic]], it is expected that one gains political debts and dispenses political favor to advance one's career or influence, if not wealth.
