{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{featured article}} {{Infobox settlement | official_name = Elcor, Minnesota | settlement_type = [[Ghost town]] | nickname = | motto = | image_skyline = | imagesize = | image_caption = | image_flag = | image_seal = | image_map = | mapsize = | map_caption = | image_map1 = | mapsize1 = | map_caption1 = | pushpin_map = Minnesota#USA | subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] | subdivision_name = United States | subdivision_type1 = [[U.S. state|State]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Minnesota]] | subdivision_type2 = [[List of counties in Minnesota|County]] | subdivision_name2 = [[St. Louis County, Minnesota|St. Louis]] | government_footnotes = | government_type = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title1 = | leader_name1 = | established_title = | established_date = | unit_pref = | area_footnotes = | area_magnitude = | area_total_km2 = | area_land_km2 = | area_water_km2 = | area_total_sq_mi = | area_land_sq_mi = | area_water_sq_mi = | population_as_of = | population_footnotes = | population_total = | population_density_km2 = | population_density_sq_mi = | timezone = [[Central Time Zone|Central (CST)]] | utc_offset = -6 | timezone_DST = CDT | utc_offset_DST = -5 | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_ft = 1542 | coordinates = {{coord|47|30|19|N|92|26|28|W|region:US-MN|display=inline,title}} | postal_code_type = | postal_code = | area_code = [[Area code 218|218]] | blank_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID | blank_info = 661197 | blank1_name = | blank1_info = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Elcor''' is a [[ghost town]], or more properly, an extinct town, in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Minnesota]] that was inhabited between 1897 and 1956. It was built on the [[Mesabi Range|Mesabi Iron Range]] near the city of [[Gilbert, Minnesota|Gilbert]] in [[St. Louis County, Minnesota|St. Louis County]]. Elcor was its own unincorporated community before it was abandoned and was never a neighborhood proper of the city of Gilbert.{{cite news|title=Elcor: A gentle, good neighborhood now more than 50 years gone|url=http://www.virginiamn.com/archives/elcor-a-gentle-good-neighborhood-now-more-than-years-gone/article_d69c8dc6-ce17-5523-afda-cd2ef53aba50.html|accessdate=May 9, 2016|publisher=''[[Mesabi Daily News]] (MN)''|date=March 18, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180318231056/http://www.virginiamn.com/archives/elcor-a-gentle-good-neighborhood-now-more-than-years-gone/article_d69c8dc6-ce17-5523-afda-cd2ef53aba50.html|archivedate=March 18, 2018|df=}} Not rating a figure in the national census, the people of Elcor were only generally considered to be citizens of Gilbert.{{cite news|author=|url= |title=Elcor-People and the Place|newspaper=Gilbert Herald (MN)|page=1|date=April 14, 1982}} The area where Elcor was located was [[Municipal annexation in the United States|annexed]] by Gilbert when its existing city boundaries were expanded after 1969.{{cite web|title=USGS Historical Topographic Map Explorer|url=http://historicalmaps.arcgis.com/usgs/|publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]|accessdate=March 11, 2017}} In November 1890, the [[Seven Iron Brothers|seven Merritt brothers]] discovered ore near [[Mountain Iron, Minnesota|Mountain Iron]], triggering an unparalleled iron rush to the Mesabi Range.{{sfn|Havinghurst|1958|pp=75–76}} The Elba mine was opened in 1897, and the town was [[plat]]ted under the direction of Don H. Bacon, president of the Minnesota Iron Company. A second nearby mine, the Corsica, was opened in 1901. The community was first called "Elba" after the name of the first underground mine (the name "Elcor" was formed later by combining the first syllables of each mine's name). The Elba and Corsica mines were both leased by [[Pickands Mather and Company]] after the formation of the [[United States Steel Corporation]].{{sfn|Van Brunt|1921|p=469}}{{cite web|title=State Minerals Leases|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/lands_minerals/min_leases.html|publisher=Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|accessdate=February 13, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524040853/http://http/|archivedate=May 24, 2011|df=}} An influx of people of many ethnicities and many nations followed, and Elcor became a microcosm of U.S. immigration, mirroring the cultural assimilation of the time.{{cite web|last1=Abramitzky|first1=Ran|title=What history tells us about assimilation of immigrants|url=https://siepr.stanford.edu/news/what-history-tells-us-about-assimilation-immigrants|website=Stanford University|publisher=Stanford Institute for Economic Policy Research|accessdate=October 23, 2017|date=April 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170914190725/https://siepr.stanford.edu/news/what-history-tells-us-about-assimilation-immigrants|archivedate=September 14, 2017|df=}} At its peak around 1920, Elcor had two churches, a post office, a [[general store]], a primary school, a railroad station, and its own law enforcement, and housed a population of nearly 1,000. Elcor was a mining location, built by the mining company to house the workers for its mines. People were allowed to own their homes, but the land on which the houses stood belonged to the mining company.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}}{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=4}} After the Corsica mine closed in 1954, Pickands Mather and Company ordered the residents to vacate the property so that it could [[Mine reclamation|reclaim]] the land; by 1956, Elcor was completely abandoned.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=107}} The desolate property changed hands often through acquisitions, mergers, and bankruptcies. In 1993, the [[Inland Steel Company]] began [[Stockpile|stockpiling]] the [[overburden]] from what is now the Minorca Mine over Elcor's former location.{{cite journal|last=Glavan|first=Gregory|title=Elcor, An Iron Range Ghost Town: The Elcor Smokestack|journal=Range Reminiscing|date=September 1999|volume=24|page=2}} ==History== ===Establishment=== Elcor came into existence with the opening of the Elba mine in 1897 and ended with the closing of the Corsica mine in 1954.{{cite journal|last=Breining|first=Greg|title=Mesabi Ghosts|journal=The Minnesota Volunteer|pages=44–53|publisher= Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|date=July–August 1992|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/mcvmagazine/archive.html?keyword=Mesabi%20Ghosts|accessdate=May 19, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630021634/http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/mcvmagazine/archive.html?keyword=Mesabi%20Ghosts|archivedate=June 30, 2015|df=}}{{cite journal|last=Breining|first=Greg|title=Ghost Towns on the Range|journal=[[Minnesota Monthly]]|date=March 1982|pages=17–19}}{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=3}} The town was originally known as Elba, between the present-day cities of [[McKinley, St. Louis County, Minnesota|McKinley]] and Gilbert; the name "Elcor" was chosen later, by combining the first syllable of the name of each mine.{{cite news|author=|title=Iron Range History: Elcor (Elba-Corsica) Memories|newspaper=[[Mesabi Daily News]] (MN)|page=13|date=October 14, 1976}}{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=5}}{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=100}} As an Iron Range mining location, Elcor originally consisted of a grid of houses the mining company rented to its employees.{{cite news|last=Holten|first=Jon|title=Elcor, City of Memories, Comes Alive Once Again|newspaper=[[Star Tribune|Minneapolis Star and Tribune]] (MN)|pages= 3C, 7C|date=July 5, 1982}} It was one of nearly 50 mining locations between the present-day cities of [[Eveleth, Minnesota|Eveleth]] and [[Aurora, Minnesota|Aurora]].{{cite journal|last=Alanen|first=Arnold|title=The 'Locations', Company Communities on Minnesota's Iron Ranges|url=http://collections.mnhs.org/MNHistoryMagazine/articles/48/v48i03p094-107.pdf|journal=Minnesota History|date=Fall 1982|pages=94–107|publisher=[[Minnesota Historical Society]]|accessdate=April 14, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019164716/http://collections.mnhs.org/mnhistorymagazine/articles/48/v48i03p094-107.pdf|archivedate=October 19, 2012|df=}} Some of these, like Sparta{{cite web|title=Sparta, MN|url=http://www.mesabitrail.com/communities/Sparta/|website=Mesabi Trail|publisher=St. Louis & Lake Counties Regional Railroad Authority|accessdate=August 3, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170720135042/http://www.mesabitrail.com/communities/sparta|archivedate=July 20, 2017|df=}} and Pineville, exist today; others, such as Franklin{{cite news |last1=Romsaas |first1=Jim |title=Village of Franklin: Alive in Iron Range Lore |url=https://www.virginiamn.com/archives/village-of-franklin-alive-in-iron-range-lore/article_a6175a02-21d4-5056-aaf0-bf149b3c12aa.html |accessdate=September 24, 2018 |publisher=[[Mesabi Daily News]] |date=March 18, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180924024047/https://www.virginiamn.com/archives/village-of-franklin-alive-in-iron-range-lore/article_a6175a02-21d4-5056-aaf0-bf149b3c12aa.html |archivedate=September 23, 2018}} and Genoa, have been annexed by adjacent communities; most have disappeared entirely.{{sfn|Van Brunt|1921|pp=455–456}}{{cite web|last1=Bordeau|first1=Sanford P.|last2=Krause|first2=James L.|last3=Krause|first3=Kathie I.|title=An Early History of Weimer, Sparta, Genoa and Gilbert, Minnesota|url=http://www.angelfire.com/mn3/gilbert/gilberthistory.html|website=|publisher=''Gilbert Herald (MN)''|accessdate=August 3, 2017|date=2002}} Development of the Elba mine was carried out by the Minnesota Iron Company, and the first shipment of [[ore]] was made in 1898.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=100}}{{cite journal|title=Historic Scene at the Village of Elcor, Mesabi Iron Range|journal=Skillings' Mining Review|date=November 19, 1960|page=27}} The Minnesota Iron Company also had a [[controlling interest]] in Petit and Robinson, which owned the Corsica mine, where the first ore was shipped in 1901. Don H. Bacon, who joined the Minnesota Iron Company as general manager in 1887 and eventually became its president, was an ardent traveler who named many mines after Mediterranean islands, including [[Malta]], [[Majorca|Maiorica]], [[Corsica]], and [[Elba]]. He had a penchant for names beginning with the letter M. The Minnesota Steamship Company was organized by, and [[vertically integrated]] with, the Minnesota Iron Company to carry ore in 1889; its steamers and barges all had names that began with M, and the ships were referred to as the M fleet. Elba's street and avenue names also all began with M:{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=3}}{{sfn|Havinghurst|1958|pp=44, 47}} [[File:Copy_of_Elcor_Townsite_Plat_2.jpg|thumb|alt=Elcor townsite plat|Elcor townsite plat, c. 1921{{en dash}}1926{{cite map | author1=Frank A. Wildes | author2=Minnesota State Auditor, Land Department | year= | title=Superintendent of Mines Subject Files, 1921–1932 | scale= [1:4,800] | location=St. Paul, MN | publisher=State Archives, Minnesota Historical Society | section= | oclc= }}]] [[Mohawk people|Mohawk]] Street
Malta Street
[[Manila|Manilla]] Street (this was also the main street)
[[Majo|Manola]] Street
[[Yokuts people|Mariposa]] Avenue
[[Mauna Loa]] Avenue
[[Maritana]] Avenue
[[Minorca]] Avenue The first street in Elba was Manilla Street. Company houses were constructed on both sides of it.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=101}} The Elba group of mines was between 1 and 1.5 miles west of McKinley, and was usually classed with the McKinley district mines, which included the Elba and Corsica mines, and the La Belle mine, operated by the Pitt Iron Mining Company.{{sfn|Woodbridge & Pardee|1910|p=737}} The Minnesota Iron Company operated the Elba mine from 1898 to 1900 under the direction of M. E. McCarthy. Immediately after the formation of the United States Steel Corporation in 1901, Pickands Mather and Company acquired the Elba and Corsica mines, assuming the mineral leases and operating both after that date.{{sfn|Van Brunt|1921|p=469}}{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=3}}{{sfn|Havinghurst|1958|pp=70, 79}} Owners James Pickands, [[Samuel Mather]] and Jay Morse had been interested in the Corsica iron-ore properties for some time, and the mines remained on the firm's shipping roll for many years. William Philip Chinn was appointed superintendent of the Elba and adjacent Corsica mine under the new management of Pickands Mather and Company, succeeding McCarthy.{{cite journal|title=William Philip Chinn, General Manager, Pickands Mather & Company: A Biography|journal=The Explosives Engineer|date=January 1930}} Chinn was then on his way up in mining circles, ultimately becoming general manager of all Pickands Mather mining properties in the Lake Superior region in 1918; he was succeeded as superintendent of the Elba and Corsica mines by L. C. David.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=3}}{{sfn|Appleby|1920|pp=56, 62, 151}} The [[Oliver Iron Mining Company]] also owned what they designated the "Elba No. 1 and No. 2 Reserve" ore bodies, but these were entirely different from the Elba and Corsica mines and remained undeveloped.{{sfn|Van Brunt|1921|p=469}}{{sfn|Appleby|1920|p=53}} === Peak years === The community grew at the beginning of the century. In 1902, the Corsica mine began operating in earnest and houses were quickly built.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=102}} Company houses were built among the tall timbers. The community thrived on iron mining, its population nearing 1,000 after World War I, resulting in a neat and comfortable location comprising more than 100 houses.{{sfn|Woodbridge & Pardee|1910|p=737|}} The townspeople were [[American pioneer|pioneers]] and largely immigrants, including [[Croatians]], [[Slovenians]], [[Finns]], [[Italians]], [[Germans]], Scandinavians, and English, particularly from [[Cornwall]].{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|pp=4, 25}} {{cite news | last= Eldot | first= Walter | title= Death of a Mining Town | newspaper= [[Duluth News Tribune]] (MN) | pages= 4–5 (Cosmopolitan Section) | date= July 17, 1955 }} [[File:Elcor, MN.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Elcor in about 1916 showing boardwalks, 4 board fences and installation of powerlines|Elcor c. 1916, showing power lines, boardwalk, and four-board fences. The Corsica mine [[smokestack|stack]] is farthest left]] In the early days, houses were made of wooden boards and surrounded by a four-board-high fence which was fronted with a [[boardwalk]]. Most of the streets were dirt roads. Winters were bitterly cold, and teams of horses dragging V-shaped wooden plows cleared the streets.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=20}} {{cite news | title= Vanished Town of Elcor Still Exists in Ex-Residents' Memories | last= Fleichtinger | first= Gail | date= July 6, 1982 | newspaper= [[Duluth News Tribune]] (MN) | pages= 1A, 8A }} In the center of town was the community pump, from which the village would draw water at stipulated hours. Water was pumped from the mine twice a day through a big open pipe. Everyone had to carry water home during pumping time. There was no shutoff valve, so buckets, tubs, and barrels were used for water storage.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=4}}{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=104}} Later, a water tower was built to hold water drawn from a deep well. [[St. Bernard (dog)|St. Bernard]] dogs helped carry the water from the well to the homes. Running water and bathtubs came only after ditches were dug for pipes to provide water from Gilbert around 1916.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=4}} Kerosene lamps provided the means of lighting until 1916, when power lines were installed.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=4}}{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=104}} Initially, the only telephone was at the Elba mine office.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=15}} The community's Finns organized a [[temperance society]] and built the Finnish Temperance Hall.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=105}} The community also included a band, a volunteer fire department, tennis courts, and a clubhouse for employees.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=5}}{{sfn|Woodbridge & Pardee|1910|p=737}} A small [[Methodism|Methodist]] church and [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian]] church were built.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=104}} The town also had a night watchman and later a full-time patrolman.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=4}} Always noted as a quiet, orderly town, Elcor managed to avoid the social vagaries of adjacent communities, like Gilbert's [[red-light district]].{{cite news|author=|title=Citizens group denounces town's 'Whorehouse Days'|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/offbeat/2005-01-27-gilbert_x.htm|accessdate=May 23, 2014|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=January 27, 2005}} One of the frame houses was used as the first school in Elcor.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=103}} It was not long before a new school was constructed. Elcor was included in the middle part of the Gilbert School system, known then as Independent School District No. 18. There were five schoolhouses in the district. The McKinley-Elba school was built in 1900, halfway between McKinley and Elba, complete with its own well and windmill.{{sfn|Van Brunt|1921|p=462}} It had four teachers and housed classes through the [[eighth grade]], accommodating pupils of both communities.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=4}}{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=103}} Students walked to school over boardwalks. There were also three primary schools in the district, one of them in Elba on Malta Street.{{sfn|Van Brunt|1921|p=462}} Elcor's renters were required to take in boarders.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=3}} The company rented a "cottage" for $7.50 per month, which later included electricity. Homes were charged an additional dollar per month when water was piped in from Gilbert. Although people were later allowed to own their homes (even though the land on which the houses stood belonged to the mining company), rents were never increased.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}} All families had their own gardens in which they grew vegetables that lasted through the winter. Some raised cows, pigs, and chickens; others had horses for carrying firewood.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=5}} There was little refrigeration, and perishables were difficult to keep.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=16}} Before the Mercantile came to Elcor, residents went to the J. P. Ahlin store in McKinley, or to the Saari, Campbell and Kraker Mercantile in Gilbert.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=4}} Deliveries were made daily, with orders taken for the following day. People bought on credit and paid monthly, on paydays.{{sfn|''Gilbert Centennial''|2008|p=15}} In 1920, the Finnish Hall became a general store, the Elcor Mercantile, along with an official U.S. Post Office.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}} When the post office began operation, much confusion resulted, because there was another town named [[Elba, Minnesota|Elba]] in southeastern Minnesota, just east of [[Rochester, Minnesota|Rochester]].{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}}{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=5}} The name "Corsica" was attempted with the same result.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}} Finally, the community was named "Elcor", combining the first syllable of each of the two names.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}}{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=5}} "Elcor" was emblazoned in large white letters on the water tower.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}} Mail was picked up twice daily at the railroad station, erroneously named "Elcore", for the [[Duluth and Iron Range Railroad]] (later the [[Duluth, Missabe and Iron Range|Duluth, Missabe and Iron Range Railroad]]).{{sfn|Upham|2001|p=520}}{{sfn|Leighton|1998|p=10}}{{cite gnis|2123651|Elcore Station (historical)|accessdate=July 28, 2017}} Later, the Elcor Mercantile diversified into the up-and-coming petroleum business, selling [[Conoco]] gasoline, kerosene, fuel oils, motor oils, grease, and even [[outboard motors]].{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=16}} Concrete [[sidewalks]] were built to line the shady streets, and bright red [[fire hydrants]] were installed.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}} Homes were [[Building insulation|insulated]], and people began to purchase refrigerators.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=16}} Manilla Street and Maritana Avenue were paved. [[Greyhound Bus Lines]] established a stop at the Elcor Mercantile.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=16}} A [[baseball]] team was entered in the old East Mesaba League,{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=105}} and the Elcor Mercantile sponsored the Elcor-Conocos, an [[ice hockey]] team that became one of the best on the Iron Range.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=16}} [[Chicago Blackhawks]] ice hockey goaltender [[Sam LoPresti]] was born in Elcor.{{cite web|title=Sam L. LoPresti|url=http://www.ushockeyhalloffame.com/page/show/818899-sam-l-lopresti|publisher=U.S. Hockey Hall of Fame|accessdate=November 4, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729012325/http://www.ushockeyhalloffame.com/page/show/818899-sam-l-lopresti|archivedate=July 29, 2017|df=}} [[File:Elcor Aerial 1948.jpg|thumb|alt=Aerial view of Elcor before its abandonment|Aerial Photo of Elcor in 1948, before its abandonment{{cite web|title=St. Louis County Aerial Photography|url=http://www.stlouiscountymn.gov/LANDPROPERTY/Maps/AerialPhotography.aspx|publisher=[[Minnesota Department of Natural Resources]]|accessdate=October 8, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925160156/http://www.stlouiscountymn.gov/LANDPROPERTY/Maps/AerialPhotography.aspx|archivedate=September 25, 2013|df=dmy-all}}]] The Corsica and Elba mines remained the chief source of employment until 1926, when the underground Elba mine closed.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=100}} It had been mined out. A few years later, the Corsica mine was converted into an open pit, and the future of the town once again seemed secure.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=106}} Then the [[Great Depression]] hit. In the fall of 1929, Corsica closed and stayed closed for many years, with only a few salaried people retained.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=16}} The mine remained idle until 1940, ironically receiving an honorable mention in the National Safety Competition from the [[U.S. Bureau of Mines]] in 1934.{{cite journal|last1=Adams|first1=William W.|title=1934 National Safety Competition|journal=The Explosives Engineer|date=July 1935|volume=13-14|page=219|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l-7mAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA219&lpg=PA219&dq=Elcor,+Minnesota&source=bl&ots=JQx17DYlQl&sig=wq9l4niWgCNeEDPaQja9aEhoSY8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwimmeqS8dTSAhUMyoMKHY3HD2s4HhDoAQgiMAI#v=onepage&q=Elcor%2C%20Minnesota&f=false|accessdate=July 29, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920210031/https://books.google.com/books?id=l-7mAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA219&lpg=PA219&dq=Elcor,+Minnesota&source=bl&ots=JQx17DYlQl&sig=wq9l4niWgCNeEDPaQja9aEhoSY8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwimmeqS8dTSAhUMyoMKHY3HD2s4HhDoAQgiMAI#v=onepage&q=Elcor%2C%20Minnesota&f=false|archivedate=September 20, 2017|df=}} Once [[World War II]] began, the mining business boomed again.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=107}} === Abandonment === [[File:Elcor Aerial Photo, 1961.jpg|thumb|alt=Aerial view of Elcor after its abandonment|Aerial Photo of Elcor in 1961, after abandonment]] In 1954, the Corsica pit was shut down. Workers were told that the shutdown was temporary because the demand for that particular type of ore had declined.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=100}} The pit was allowed to flood, and Pickands Mather officially conceded that "temporary" might stretch into quite a long time, although the mine would perhaps "eventually" be reopened.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=100}} A year later, Pickands Mather and Company, manager of the mines at Elcor and the land on which the houses rested, ordered residents to vacate the property.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=107}} By edict of the mining company, the remaining families were forced out so that the company could reclaim the land.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=107}} Sources differ on why the order was issued, speculating that the company wanted the land for a dump site, no longer wanted to tend to the town's maintenance, or decided it was not economical to own houses anymore.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=24}} No one in authority revealed what was to become of the land. Residents of the company-owned houses were given the option to buy the structures at bargain prices, provided they moved them out of town.{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=8}}{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=108}} For many, it took much of their life savings to relocate elsewhere, taking their homes in caravans along the highways and leaving behind empty foundations. Most Elcor residents purchased lots in the surrounding communities, trying to beat land [[speculators]]. In the few months after Elcor's fate became official, land prices skyrocketed. Lots that had originally been priced at $75 were sold for as much as $500. Most of the remaining families moved about two miles west to Gilbert, although other homes were replanted in nearby McKinley. The last vestiges of the old mining community were gone by 1956.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=100}}{{sfn|Phillipich et al.|1982|p=5}} Every building was torn down or removed.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=108}} All that remained for some years after were old foundations, sidewalks, rusting stoves, pipes, bottles, and yard shrubbery, formerly visible from the old section of [[Minnesota State Highway 135]] between Gilbert and [[Biwabik, Minnesota|Biwabik]]. A rusted fire hydrant adorned what was once a street corner, and a porcelain toilet bowl remained bolted to a concrete floor. An abandoned rail line for the Duluth, Missabe and Iron Range Railway went through what was left of the town site. Mine shafts were boarded up with old timbers. After everyone had left, the company dumped heaps of iron ore on the roads leading into Elcor, and in the process a ghost town was made out of what was once a thriving community.{{sfn|Lamppa|1962|p=100}} [[File:Corsica_Mine_Smokestack_Elcor_Minnesota.jpg|thumb|left|upright|alt=Corsica mine smokestack prior to its demolition|Corsica mine smokestack before its demolition, c. 1967]] For a time, the only landmark that remained at the old mining location was a {{convert|200|ft|m|adj=on}} smokestack near the defunct Corsica mine.{{cite news|last=Leschak|first=Pam|title=There She Blows-Finally! Attempt to Save it Too Late: Old Stack Blasted Down|newspaper=Hibbing Daily Tribune (MN)|pages=1, 12|date=September 28, 1976}}{{cite news|last=Radomski|first=Robyn|title=Last Stack Bombed: Old Stack Blown; Protests Overridden|newspaper=[[Mesabi Daily News]] (MN)|page=1|date=September 28, 1976}} The stack, built by [[Cornish people|Cornish]] miners in 1901, had a unique design.{{cite news|author=|title=Before...and After|newspaper=Gilbert Herald (MN)|page=6|date=September 29, 1976}} The [[Iron Range Historical Society]] wanted the stack, the last of its kind on the Mesabi Iron Range, to be preserved as an off-premises attraction, since it was structurally sound and historically significant, but its demolition had already been contracted as a part of the Minnesota Mineland Reclamation Act Abandoned Minelands Cleanup Program.{{cite web|title=Minnesota Mineland Reclamation Act|url=https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/pre2003/other/880685.pdf|publisher=Minnesota Legislative Reference Library|accessdate=March 21, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322111049/https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/pre2003/other/880685.pdf|archivedate=March 22, 2017|df=}}{{cite journal|last=Leschak|first=Pam|title=Big Clean-Up on the Iron Range|journal=The Minnesota Volunteer|pages=37–41|publisher=Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|date=September–October 1977|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/mcvmagazine/archive.html?keyword=Big%20Clean-Up%20on%20the%20Iron%20Range|accessdate=November 19, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150630013028/http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/mcvmagazine/archive.html?keyword=Big%20Clean-Up%20on%20the%20Iron%20Range|archivedate=June 30, 2015|df=}}{{cite web|title=Mineland Reclamation|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/lands_minerals/mineland_reclamation/index.html|publisher=Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|accessdate=March 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311195954/http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/lands_minerals/mineland_reclamation/index.html|archivedate=March 11, 2014|df=}}{{cite web|title=Mineland Reclamation |url=http://mn.gov/irrrb/miningtimber/mineland-reclamation/ |publisher=[[Iron Range Resources and Rehabilitation Board]] |accessdate=March 6, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309091040/http://mn.gov/irrrb/miningtimber/mineland-reclamation/ |archivedate=March 9, 2014 |df= }} Many people feared it might fall and injure someone; others considered it an aerial obstruction. In 1976, the stack was destroyed; it took three blasting attempts and nearly {{convert|100|lb|kg}} of [[dynamite]] to bring the structure down. After the demolition, responsibility for the land on which Elcor stood changed hands on several different occasions. As early as 1978, the property and its management were acquired by the [[Jones and Laughlin Steel Company]]. Property rights were then transferred to [[LTV Steel]] after the merger of Jones and Laughlin with [[Republic Steel]] in 1984. Property rights were later acquired by the Inland Steel Company in a transfer from LTV. In 1993, Inland Steel began stripping the overburden near the old town site, and the Laurentian mine was born.{{cite web |title=Laurentian Taconite Mine Draft Environmental Impact Statement |url=https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/pre2003/other/900445.pdf |publisher=Minnesota Legislative Reference Library |accessdate=August 19, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180819004444/https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/pre2003/other/900445.pdf|archivedate=August 19, 2018|df=}}{{cite web |title=Laurentian Taconite Mine Final Environmental Impact Statement |url=https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/pre2003/other/900562.pdf |publisher=Minnesota Legislative Reference Library |accessdate=August 19, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180819003646/https://www.leg.state.mn.us/docs/pre2003/other/900562.pdf|archivedate=August 19, 2018|df=}} The mine is now owned by [[ArcelorMittal]] and has been redesignated the Laurentian pit of the Minorca mine after the acquisition of Inland Steel by [[Mittal Steel Company|Mittal]] in 1998.{{cite web|title=USA Operations|url=http://www.usa.arcelormittal.com/our-operations/mining|publisher=ArcelorMittal|accessdate=March 6, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306174303/http://usa.arcelormittal.com/Our-operations/Mining/|archivedate=March 6, 2014|df=}} {{clear}} ==Geology== Elcor sat atop a bed of [[taconite]] consisting of a uniform mixture of about 30 percent iron, interspersed with pockets of high-grade ore containing 90 to 95 percent iron,{{sfn|Davis|1964|p=1}} a part of the Biwabik iron formation. The formation is a large sheet of iron-bearing sediment deposited during the [[Precambrian]] era on the bottom of the [[Animikie Group|Animikie Sea]]. This sea occupied the western portion of the [[Great Lakes]] area, depositing iron-bearing sediments extending under Lake Superior from the [[Mesabi Range|Mesabi]] and [[Vermilion Iron Range]]s in northern Minnesota, to the [[Gogebic Range|Gogebic Iron Range]] in northern [[Wisconsin]] and [[Michigan]]'s upper peninsula, to the [[Marquette Iron Range|Marquette Range]] of the upper peninsula, and west to the [[manganese]]-rich ore of the [[Cuyuna Range|Cuyuna Iron Range]] in central Minnesota.{{sfn|Davis|1964|p=31}} Michigan's [[Silicon dioxide|silicious]] steel-blue high-grade ores were quite different from the Mesabi ore, which was hydrated soft brown [[hematite]].{{sfn|Van Hise|1901|p=337}}{{sfn|Crowell & Murray|1914|p=229}}{{sfn|Havinghurst|1958|p=47}} Geologists disagree about the geologic time period of the region and the mechanism by which the iron-bearing sediment was laid down differently on opposite sides of the lake.{{sfn|Davis|1964|p=34}} There is iron ore in other areas of Minnesota, but no longer in quantities that are practical to mine.{{cite journal|last=Pederson|first=C. A.|title=Southern Minnesota's Iron Mines|journal=The Minnesota Volunteer|pages=48–50|publisher=Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|date=March–April 1958|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/mcvmagazine/archive.html?keyword=Southern%20Minnesota's%20Iron%20Mines|accessdate=May 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303214353/http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/mcvmagazine/archive.html?keyword=Southern%20Minnesota%27s%20Iron%20Mines|archivedate=March 3, 2016|df=}} Geologists divide the iron-bearing rocks of the eastern Mesabi Iron Range into several layers. In the [[stratigraphic column]], [[Virginia Slate]] and [[Duluth Complex|Duluth gabbro]] lie above, followed by four main iron-bearing divisions named the Upper Slaty, Upper Cherty, Lower Slaty, and Lower Cherty. Below these are [[quartzite]] and [[granite]]. Beneath the shallow [[topsoil]], the slate is from {{convert|50|ft|m}} to several hundred feet thick, and the four iron-bearing layers are from {{convert|400|to|600|ft|m}} thick.{{sfn|Davis|1964|p=34}} ==Geography and climate== Elcor lay at an elevation of {{convert|1542|ft|m}} in St. Louis County, Minnesota, {{convert|52|mi|km}} [[Boxing the compass|north-northwest]] of [[Duluth, Minnesota|Duluth]].{{cite gnis|661197|Elcor|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} The nearest cities to Elcor were Gilbert, approximately {{convert|2|mi|km|0}} to the southwest and McKinley, approximately {{convert|2|mi|km|0}} to the east-northeast. Elcor was along the old section of Minnesota State Highway 135, almost {{convert|5|mi|km|0}} east-southeast of [[U.S. Route 53]] and about {{convert|2|mi|km|0}} northeast of [[Minnesota State Highway 37]].{{Cite map|publisher=[[Minnesota Department of Transportation|Minnesota Department of Highways]]|title=Minnesota Official Highway Map|year=1960|scale=[1:760,320]|url=http://cdm16022.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/mdt/id/1198|accessdate=December 6, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171207015743/http://cdm16022.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/mdt/id/1198|archivedate=December 7, 2017|df=}} Elcor was in the [[Laurentian Mixed Forest Province]] in the [[Arrowhead region]] of northern Minnesota. The [[polar air mass]] dominates this part of the state year-round. Precipitation ranges from about {{convert|21|in|cm}} annually along the western border of the forest to about {{convert|32|in|cm}} at its eastern edge. Average annual temperatures are about {{convert|34|F|C}} along the northern part of the forest, rising to {{convert|40|F|C}} at its southern extreme.{{cite web|title=Laurentian Mixed Forest Province|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/ecs/212/index.html|publisher= Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|accessdate=May 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140520001754/http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/ecs/212/index.html|archivedate=May 20, 2014|df=}} Normal annual snowfall totals about {{convert|60|in|cm}}.{{cite web|title=Minnesota Annual Snow Normal|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/climate/summaries_and_publications/normals_snow_1981_2010.html|publisher=Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|accessdate=December 7, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160721223858/http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/climate/summaries_and_publications/normals_snow_1981_2010.html|archivedate=July 21, 2016|df=}} July is the warmest month, when the average high temperature is {{convert|78|F|C}} and the average low is {{convert|51|F|C}}. January is the coldest, with an average high temperature of {{convert|18|F|C}} and average low of {{convert|-5|F|C}}. Elcor was approximately {{convert|22|miles}} south-southwest of [[Tower, Minnesota]], where the temperature reached a record low of {{convert|-60|F|C}} on February 2, 1996.{{cite web|title=Minnesota Climate Extremes|url=http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/climate/summaries_and_publications/extremes.html|publisher= Minnesota Department of Natural Resources|accessdate=May 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140522033445/http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/climate/summaries_and_publications/extremes.html|archivedate=May 22, 2014|df=}} ==See also== {{notability|Organizations|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox organization | name = Forum of Federations | bgcolor = | fgcolor = | image = | image_border = | size = | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = | motto = The Global Network on Federalism and Devolved Governance | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date|1999}} | extinction = | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | status = ''[[Not for profit]]'' | purpose = Educational events on governance issues; development assistance and publications related to [[federalism]] and [[democracy]] | headquarters = 75 Albert Street
Suite 411
[[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]
K1P 5E7 | location = | coords = | region_served = | membership = Australia, Brazil, Canada, Ethiopia, Germany, India, Mexico, Nigeria, Pakistan and Switzerland | language = (publications) [[French language|French]], [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Arabic]], [[Nepali language|Nepali]], [[Sinhala language|Sinhala]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]] | leader_title = President | leader_name = Rupak Chattopadhyay | leader_title2 = Chairman of the Board | leader_name2 = [[Georg Milbradt]] | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = http://www.forumfed.org/ | remarks = | former name = }} The '''Forum of Federations''' is an international organization based in [[Ottawa|Ottawa, Ontario]], [[Canada]]. The Forum and its partners form a global network on [[federalism]]. It brings together elected officials, [[civil servant]]s and experts in federalism from about 20 countries to learn from each other.{{clarify|date=May 2015}} The Forum's learning and technical assistance programs have covered the following countries: Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Burma, Canada, Ethiopia, Germany, India, Italy, Kenya, Libya, Malaysia, Mexico, Nepal, Nigeria, Pakistan, Philippines, Russia, Spain, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Sudan, South Sudan, Switzerland, Tunisia and Yemen. ==Organization== The Forum of [[Federation]]s is an international network of federal [[country|countries]], [[elected official]]s, [[civil servant]]s and [[scholar]]s. The Forum was established by the [[Government of Canada]] in 1999 and currently has nine other partner governments: [[Government of Australia|Australia]], [[Government of Brazil|Brazil]], [[Government of Ethiopia|Ethiopia]], [[Government of Germany|Germany]], [[Government of India|India]], [[Government of Mexico|Mexico]], [[Government of Nigeria|Nigeria]], [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan]] and [[Government of Switzerland|Switzerland]]. Forum's headquarters are in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, and it has field offices in [[Kathmandu]], Nepal, [[Addis Ababa]], Ethiopia, and [[Yangon]], Myanmar.http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/local/6062/ The Forum runs training and knowledge sharing programs to address governance challenges in existing and emerging federations, as well as in devolved and decentralized countries. The Forum is concerned with the contribution that multi-level government can make to democracy building and democratic consolidation. • The Forum assists in democracy promotion in fragile states or regions in post-conflict situation. • It provides innovative solutions to challenges posed by multi-level governance in federal, devolved, and decentralized countries. • It focuses on the key issues of local empowerment and federal structures. • It provides expertise that bridges the worlds of academic research and real-world practice. The Forum runs learning events on federalism, gives technical advice on democratic governance and produces publications for academics and practitioners of federalism. Its activities involve working with government officials{{cite web|url=http://www.forumfed.org/en/events/event.php?id=573 |title=Robust metropolitan regions drive economic and demographic growth, conference told |publisher=Forum of Federations |accessdate=2011-09-20}} as well as academic experts,{{cite web|url=http://www.forumfed.org/en/events/event.php?id=632 |title=Canada and Argentina on opposite ends of the federal spectrum |publisher=Forum of Federations |accessdate=2011-09-20}} young professionals,{{cite web|url=http://www.forumfed.org/en/events/event.php?id=631 |title=Federalism training for young professionals launched in Switzerland |publisher=Forum of Federations|accessdate=2011-09-20}} journalists{{cite web| url=http://www.forumfed.org/en/events/event.php?id=515 |title=Sudanese learn from other federal countries |publisher= Forum of Federations |accessdate=2011-09-20}} and other civil society organizations. The Forum works globally – in the Americas, in Europe, in Africa, and in Asia-Pacific. == Activities == * Publications: Published series of books on major themes of federalism:{{cite web|url=http://mqup.mcgill.ca/book_list.php?series=50&records=20&thumbnails=yes |title=Global Dialogue on Federalism Series| publisher= [[McGill-Queen's University Press]] |accessdate=2011-09-20}} **Diversity and Unity in Federal Countries, {{ISBN|978-0-7735-3732-3}} **Local Government and Metropolitan Regions in Federal Systems, {{ISBN|978-0-7735-3562-6}} **Foreign Relations in Federal Countries, {{ISBN|978-0-7735-3501-5}} **The Practice of Fiscal Federalism, {{ISBN|978-0-7735-3301-1}} **Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Governance in Federal Countries, {{ISBN|978-0-7735-3134-5}} **Distribution of Powers and Responsibilities in Federal Countries, {{ISBN|978-0-7735-2974-8}} **Constitutional Origins, Structure, and Change in Federal Countries, {{ISBN|978-0-7735-2849-9}} * Problem-solving: Current or recent projects, as of June 2013, on federalism include courts and judicial systems, water, internal markets, gender and leadership, health care and federalism, joint service delivery, revenue sharing and decentralization, oil and gas, local and metropolitan governance, public security, climate change and environmental governance, benchmarking, immigration, and integration of newcomers. * Learning: Organizes approximately 40 events a year, workshops, roundtables, training sessions, where participants learn or refine their knowledge about the practices of federalism, and how to apply their learning in their countries. Events take place in over 20 countries. * Assisting the developing world: Development assistance programs have taken place or are planned in [[Burma]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Iraq]], [[Libya]], [[Nepal]], [[Nigeria]], [[Pakistan]], [[Philippines]], [[South Africa]], [[Sri Lanka]], [[Sudan]], South Sudan, [[Tunisia]] and [[Yemen]]. These programs provide training on federalism and decentralized governance, as well as sector specific institutional support. * Holds major international conferences: On average every three years, sponsored by [[Canada]] (1999), [[Switzerland]] (2002), [[Belgium]] (2005), [[India]] (2007) and [[Ethiopia]] (2010). Conferences are attended by heads of state and heads of government (e.g. [[Johannes Rau]], president of Germany, in 2002; Indian Prime Minister Dr. [[Manmohan Singh]] and Ethiopian Prime Minister [[Meles Zenawi]] in 2007), as well as ministers, judges, senior officials, young professionals, academics and other specialists. ==History== The Forum was founded in 1999 following the [[Clarity Act#Conference|First International Conference on Federalism]] in [[Mont-Tremblant]], [[Quebec]]. The event drew then world leaders such as U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]], Canadian Prime Minister [[Jean Chrétien]], and Mexican President [[Ernesto Zedillo]]. Four consecutive International Conferences were organized in Switzerland, Belgium, India, and Ethiopia. Over the years, the Forum has expanded the focus of its work to include not only established federal countries but also countries in post-conflict situations adopting federal forms of governance and those involved in processes of devolution and decentralization. ==Officials== {{refimprove section|date=April 2011}} * Board members: Georg Milbradt, (Chairman), Germany; Andreas Ashete, Ethiopia; Alexander Alvaro, Germany; General John de Chastelain, Canada; Naini Jayaseelan, India; Ramón Galindo Noriega, Mexico; Johanne Poirier, Canada; Hans Altherr, Switzerland; Ali Gardezi, Pakistan; Roger Wilkins, Australia. * President and Chief Executive Officer: Rupak Chattopadhyay * Fellows of the Forum: Vijay Kelkar, Arnold Koller, Prof. David Cameron, Ronald L. Watts, Thomas Pfisterer, Mian Raza Rabbani. ==References== {{Primary sources|date=September 2011}} {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.forumfed.org/}} {{Autonomous types of first-tier administration}} [[Category:Organizations based in Ottawa]] [[Category:Federalism]] [[Category:Intergovernmental organizations]] [[Category:International political organizations]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Canada]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Australia]] [[Category:Federalism in Australia]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Brazil]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Germany]] [[Category:Foreign relations of India]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Mexico]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Nigeria]] [[Category:Foreign relations of Switzerland]] [[Category:Think tanks established in 1999]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Ontario]]

The '''ICC Working Group on Business and Human Rights''' is a thematic Working Group of [[International Co-ordinating Committee of National Human Rights Institutions|the International Coordinating Committee of National Institutions for the Promotion and Protection of Human Rights (ICC)]]. The Working Group was established by the ICC Bureau in March 2009 and held its [http://www.nhri.net/2009/ICC%20WG%20BHR%20Report%20to%20ICC%20Bureau%20011109.pdf first meeting in Copenhagen in August 2009]. The Working Group includes 2 members from each of the 4 ICC Regions ([[Network of African National Human Rights Institutions|Africa]], [[Network of National Institutions in the Americas|Americas]], [[Asia Pacific Forum|Asia-Pacific]] and [[European Group of National Human Rights Institutions|Europe]]). The [[Danish Institute for Human Rights|Danish Institute for Human Rights (DIHR)]] currently holds the Chair of the Working Group. The Working Group on Business and Human Rights is the first thematic working group under the ICC. The purpose of the Working Group is to encourage collaboration between [[National human rights institutions|National Human Rights Institutions (NHRIs)]] within the Human Rights and Business field and ensure that the issue of human rights and business is included in international frameworks. == Organization == The officers of the WG are a Chair and Vice Chair. The order of succession of the offices of Chair and Vice Chair is distributed between the four ICC regions in the following order: Europe, Americas, Asia Pacific, and Africa. Each ICC Regional Chair determines the method of selection of members representing the four ICC regions. Membership of the Working Group for regional members lasts for a period of two years. If a membership of the Working Group is terminated, the relevant Regional Chair determines a replacement.
The working languages of the Working Group will be those of the ICC: English, French and Spanish. == Links to meeting documents == * {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Policy Debate}} '''Inter-collegiate policy debate''' is a form of [[Individual events (speech)|speech competition]] involving two teams of two debaters from different [[college]]s or [[university|universities]] based on a resolution phrased as something the [[United States federal government]] "should" do. [[Policy debate]] also exists as a [[high school]] activity, with a very similar format, but different leagues, tournaments, speech times, resolutions, and styles.
==Format== Each round is divided into four 9-minute [[Constructive speech|constructive]] speeches, each followed by a 3-minute cross-examination period, then four 6-minute [[Rebuttal speech|rebuttal]] speeches. The two sides alternate, with the affirmative getting the first and last speeches of the round and the negative getting the last constructive and the first rebuttal in the middle. Most affirmative teams present a specific policy option, or plan, as a normative defence of the resolution. However, some teams partake in alternative forms of debate, including performance, personal advocacies, or otherwise [[Kritik|critical]] approaches. Negatives have several options for response, including [[Stock issues|solvency]] arguments against the effectiveness of the plan, external policy [[disadvantage]]s, opportunity-cost-based [[counterplan]]s, arguments stemming from debate theory such as the failure of the affirmative to [[Topicality (policy debate)|advocate the resolution]], and critical approaches. Argument is highly [[Evidence (policy debate)|evidence]]-based, with numerous lengthy excerpts from books and articles read by each side. Speeches are often very fast, so much so as to be incomprehensible to people who are not used to the style.
==Governing organizations== Inter-collegiate policy debate has been historically overseen by the [[National Debate Tournament]] (NDT), the [[Cross Examination Debate Association]] (CEDA), and, especially in the mid-Atlantic region, the [[American Debate Association]] (ADA). Since 1996-97 these organizations have shared a common topic, and have become largely unified. They nonetheless continue to host their own national championships.
Other organizations that sponsor policy debate, albeit with different rules, are the [[National Educational Debate Association]] (NEDA) and the National Forensics Association's Lincoln Douglas (NFA-LD) debate (a policy variant of the high school [[Lincoln-Douglas debate|LD]] format, which is less commonly practiced in colleges and universities).
==Differences with high school debate== Inter-collegiate and high school policy debate are largely similar. Some of the differences:
*High school debate has its own, separate, leagues and tournaments. *High school [[Constructive speech|constructives]] are typically only 8 minutes, and high school [[Rebuttal speech|rebuttals]] are typically only 5 minutes. College times are typically 9 minute constructives and 6 minute rebuttals. *Each year, the High school [[Resolution (policy debate)|resolution]] is different from the College Policy Resolution. *College rounds tend to be more strategically complex.
Experienced college debaters often act as paid coaches, judges, and summer-camp counselors for high school policy debaters.

{{Orphan|date=March 2013}}
In [[computing]], '''kill pill''' is a term given to mechanisms and technologies designed to render [[Computer systems|systems]] useless either by user command, or under a predefined set of circumstances. Kill pill technology is most commonly used to disable lost or stolen devices for security purposes, but can also be used for the enforcement of rules and contractual obligations.
==Applications==
===Lost and stolen devices=== Kill pill technology is used prominently in [[smartphone]]s, especially in the disablement of lost or stolen devices. A notable example is [[Find My iPhone]], a service that allows the user to [[password]] protect or [[Data erasure|wipe]] their [[iDevice|iDevice(s)]] remotely, aiding in the protection of private data.<ref name=FindMyiPhone>{{cite web|title=iCloud - Find my iPhone|url=https://www.apple.com/iphone/icloud/#find|publisher=Apple Inc.|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> Similar applications exist for other smartphone [[Operating System|operating systems]], including [[Android (operating system)|Android]],<ref name=Android5Ways>{{cite web|last=Lightner|first=Rob|title=5 ways to help find your lost Android device|url=http://howto.cnet.com/8301-11310_39-20095637-285/5-ways-to-help-find-your-lost-android-device/|publisher=CNET|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> [[BlackBerry OS|BlackBerry]],<ref name=BlackBerryProtect>{{cite web|title=BlackBerry Protect|url=http://ca.blackberry.com/devices/features/security/protect.html|publisher=BlackBerry Inc.|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> and [[Windows Phone]].<ref name=FindingLostMicrosoftPhone>{{cite web|title=Finding a lost phone|url=http://www.windowsphone.com/en-ca/how-to/wp7/basics/find-a-lost-phone|publisher=Microsoft Inc.|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
===Anti-piracy measure=== Kill pill technology has been notably used as an [[Copy protection#Anti-piracy|anti-piracy]] measure. [[Windows Vista]] was released with the ability to severely limit its own functionality if it was determined that the copy was obtained through [[Software piracy|piracy]]. The feature was later dropped after complaints that [[false positive]]s caused genuine copies of Vista to act as though they were pirated.<ref name=VistaKillPill>{{cite news|title='Kill switch' dropped from Vista|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/7126902.stm|accessdate=13 February 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=4 December 2007}}</ref>
===Removal of malicious software=== The concept of a kill pill is also applied to the remote removal by a [[Server (computing)|server]] of malicious files or applications from a [[Client (computing)|client's]] system. Such technology is a standard component of most handheld computing devices, mainly due to their generally more limited operating systems and means of obtaining applications. Such functionality is also reportedly available to applications downloaded from the [[Windows Store]] on [[Windows 8]] operating systems.<ref name=Win8KillSwitch>{{cite news|last=Robertson|first=Jordan|title=The Kill Switch Comes to the PC|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-02-17/the-kill-switch-comes-to-the-pc|accessdate=13 February 2013|newspaper=Businessweek|date=16 February 2012}}</ref>
===Vehicles=== Kill pill technology is used frequently in [[Motor vehicle|vehicles]] for a variety of reasons. Remote vehicle disablement can be used to prevent a vehicle from starting, to prevent it from moving, and to prevent the vehicle's continued operation. Non-remotely, vehicles can require driver recognition before starting or moving, such as asking for a password or some form of [[biometrics]] from the driver.<ref name=VehicleKillPill>{{cite web|title=Vehicle Disabling Systems|url=http://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/facts-research/systems-technology/product-guides/vehicle-disabling.htm|publisher=US Department of Transportation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Association|accessdate=13 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221084256/http://@fmcsa.dot.gov/facts-research/systems-technology/product-guides/vehicle-disabling.htm|archivedate=21 February 2013|df=}}</ref>
Kill pill technology is often used by governments to prevent [[drunk driving]] by repeat offenders as a punishment and deterrent. The installation of an [[ignition interlock device]]s is a sentencing alternative for drunk drivers in almost all 50 of the [[United States]]. Such a device requires the driver to blow into a [[breathalyzer]] before starting the vehicle. If the driver is found to be over the legal [[blood alcohol content]] limit, the vehicle will not start<ref name=CarBreathalyzer>{{cite news|last=Cordell|first=LaDoris|title=Baby, You Can't Drive Your Car|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2009/09/baby_you_cant_drive_your_car.html|accessdate=13 February 2013|newspaper=Slate|date=22 September 2009}}</ref>
===Other uses=== Kill pill technology can also be implemented to contextually disable certain aspects of a smartphone's functionality. A patent obtained by [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] claims the ability to disable the antenna, screen, or camera of a smartphone in settings like theaters, schools, and areas of high security sensitivity.<ref name=ApplePatent>{{cite patent|country = US|number = 8254902|status = patent|title = Apparatus and methods for enforcement of policies upon a wireless device}}</ref>
==Criticism== Kill pill technology has been criticized for allowing for the suppression of personal liberties. While a kill pill can be utilized in a school setting to prevent academic dishonesty, it has been suggested that governments may also use it to suppress their people, for example, by disabling a phone's camera or antenna in the area of a protest.<ref name=ApplePatentProtest>{{cite news|last=Whittaker|first=Zack|title=Apple's patent could remotely disable protesters' phone cameras|url=http://www.zdnet.com/apple-patent-could-remotely-disable-protesters-phone-cameras-7000003640/|accessdate=13 February 2013|newspaper=ZDNet|date=4 September 2012}}</ref>
The ability to remotely remove files and applications from a user's device has also come under fire. Apple's apparent ability to [[blacklist]] applications, rendering them unusable on any iDevice, has raised concerns about the user's rights when downloading from the [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]].<ref name=AppleRemoteWipe>{{cite news|last=Buchanan|first=Matt|title=Apple Can Remotely Disable Apps Installed on Your iPhone|url=https://gizmodo.com/5034007/apple-can-remotely-disable-apps-installed-on-your-iphone|accessdate=13 February 2013|newspaper=Gizmodo|date=6 August 2008}}</ref> As of July 2014, no applications appear on Apple's blacklist website.
==See also== *[[Kill switch]]
